editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Morning Ramble, OR, THE TOWN-HUMOURS: A COMEDY.
LONDON, Printed for Thomas Dring, at the White Lyon, next Chancery-Lane end in Fleetſtreet. 1673.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: CRiticks, now boaſt your power, for you have made
A Tragick muſe run mad in maſquerade.
All Poets before him the Laws did ſlight
Of ſuch as only rail'd, but could not Write.
But he ſubmits ſo far, that you will ſwear
His firſt was writ in blood, but this i'th' Air.
'Twas nine day's work: but truly there might be
As good a Play juſt ſpoke Ex tempore.
For Whip and Spur, 'tis A-la-mode de France;
A thing made up of Fiddle, Song, and Dance.
All three your dear Delights, no matter then
Whether of ſence there be one line in ten:
This Age is not for that, 'tis much too wiſe,
VVhat Poets teach, you dull moralities;
That was their buſineſs in that humble Age,
VVhen Hedges were their Scenes, and Fields their Stage,
VVhen the poor ſimple VVorld ſtrove to be good;
Thank time, things now are better underſtood.
But yet he could not leave, you'l ſee him now
Have a ſlight paſs or two at ſome of you;
He thinks there's Bullys dare not fight, i'th' Pit
As well as Criticks, that he's ſure want wit.
One may be both — They that make moſt ado,
Do oftneſt want both wit and courage too.
But fear no common place, nor ſober ſaws,
By ſome late Plays he partly knows your Laws.
At a quaint Dance, or a Grimace that takes,
The Theatre with loud applauſes ſhakes.
But if true thought be with good Language dreſt,
You ſlightly cry, 'twas well enough expreſt.
Then as you've us'd ſome Plays, ſo do by this,
Clap but that part which wild and ſenſeleſs is,
And for what's wiſe we give you leave to hiſs.

div.head: The Firſt Act.
div.stage: Enter Townlove and Merry, with Fiddles and Torches.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: NO drawing back, Townlove, I'm engag'd, and am reſolv'd to make a Night on't.

sp.speaker: Townl.
sp.p: Prethee, Will Merry, let's part; thou know'ſt I never uſe that word to thee but when I have extraordinary bus'neſs.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Bus'neſs! what bus'neſs canſt thou have? I'le warrant you you're to be up betimes it'h Morning to ſell a parcel of fat Sheep or Oxen, new come from your Eſtate in the Countrey, or elſe to inſtruct Counſel in a Cauſe of yours depending I know not where. Bus'neſs, quoth a, that ever a well-bred Gentleman ſhould ſuffer the word to come into his Mouth.

sp.speaker: Townl.
sp.p: I tell thee, Will, I have bus'neſs, ſerious bus'neſs, and bus'neſs fit for a Gentleman; let that ſatisfie you: and ſo farewell.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Stay, Stay, this ſhan'not do, Townlove, I ſmell you out; You fear I'le carry you to ſome lewd Houſe now that abounds in Burgundy, and there top up with 'tother half dozen Bottles; then the dreadful Head-ake comes and keeps you in two dayes to be the diſappointment of Lord knows how many ſhe-friends.

sp.speaker: Townl.
sp.p: And do you think ſuch fears are not very reaſonable? A Man indeed hath ſo much time allow'd him in this World, that he ſhould neglect the Living two dayes for the delight of two hours: Prethee think, would any Man of ſenſe part with his time at that rate?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Faith, Townlove, thou art mad, diſtracted, gone, and I'm afraid, beyond recovery; thou can'ſt not conſider things I ſee.

sp.speaker: Townl.
sp.p: If want of conſideration be a ſign of madneſs, Will, thou haſt been a little craz'd ever ſince I knew thee. But prethee, what han't I conſider'd in this matter?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Living, Townlove, Living: thou haſt not ſo much as conſider'd what bus'neſs thou was ſent into the World about — Tis Living, Man.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Why, I know 'tis Living, and therefore I ſtrive to Live as much of the time I have allow'd me as I can.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Thou Live, and yet ſpeak againſt Drinking, the very thing that diſtinguiſhes the Life of Man from that of a Beaſt! Why, 'tis the onely Spur of Wit and Reaſon; I have heard more new thoughts in Drinking three hours, then the beſt Modern Play can furniſh you with; Therefore if thou would'ſt Live, that is, truly enjoy thy ſelf, Drink, I ſay, Drink.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Well, I can neither ſtay to do it, nor talk of it now; and therefore good bu'y.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nay, faith, thou ſhalt ſtay till I give a ſerenade to my Miſtreſs now, I am under the Window; ſtrike up, Boyes.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Hold; ſure Will, thou'rt mad — Doſt not know her Brother is a ſerious Gentleman, and not us'd to City frolicks; 'tis the only way to loſe her for ever.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why, this 'tis, not to underſtand Drinking, it makes one as dull and thoughtleſs as a Countrey Curate, that lives upon ſix pounds, and a caſt Caſſock two and fifty Sundayes; doſt thou think I would Marry her, if I did not intend to reclaim both her and her Brother from dull ſobriety.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Why, thou wouldeſt not have thy Wife Drink, woud'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No, but I would have her be as mad, and love thoſe that do, Women are fine thin things, the breath of a Man that is merry is ſufficient to inſpire them with wit enough for a Woman, and therefore here I declare that I will ſerenade her, and if ſhe ſhews the leaſt diſlike to the frolick, I will, in ſpight of Love and all his little tricks, diſclaim her for ever. And therefore, Boyes, to our bus'neſs; come, the Song I made.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Well, I'le ſtay to ſee thee a poor diſcarded, melancholy, diſconſolate Lover, and then I'le leave thee, and go to my Miſtreſs.

div.head: Song.
div.l: FRom Friends juſt inſpir'd with brisk Burgundy Wine,
Speaking raptures of Reaſon, and ſayings Divine.
I come — I come — from this Heav'n I come,
And through dirt and darkneſs I willingly roam,
To follow a Boy that confeſſes he's blind,
He tells me of hope, but leads me through fear,
Nay, ſometimes I'm juſt on the brink of deſpair;
Yet on I follow, I follow ſtill, leaving behind
The two mighty Bleſſings, my Bottle and Friend.
He tells me of Bliſs,
Beyond this,
Yet will not declare where my Journey ſhall end.

l.hi: Ah, what Charms have thoſe Eyes!
That a Love ſo ſtrong can inſpire,
It Mirth, Wit, and Friendſhip defies,
And Wine cannot ſlacken its fire.
Then ſpight of my ſelf I muſt follow him ſtill,
A Devil, or a God, let him be which he will,
I cannot, nay, would not retire,
No, though I were ſure to be burnt in the fire.

sp.stage: Roſe appears in a Night-Gown above.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: For Heav'ns ſake, Mr. Merry, be gone; my Miſtreſs knows who you are, but ſhould her Brother do ſo, we ſhould be ſent into the Countrey immediately.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Roſe, Roſe, I tell thee, Roſe, I would follow with this noiſe of Fiddles at my heels, and drive him back to Town, or never let him ſleep but in ſhelter of as many Night-Caps as Moroſe in the Silent Woman hath.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I am very ſerious, Sir, my Lady begs you to be gone before you wake her Brother.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Come, Roſe, confeſs, confeſs; I know thou art acquainted with a touch of thy Miſtreſſes ſecrets: Tell me, is there no other
ſeat but of being ſent into the Countrey?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Oh, yes, no doubt on't, the Miſtreſs is highly concern'd for fear of loſing the hopes of ſo ſober a Husband.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Marry, and I thought ſo. —

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: One, that if a Body has occaſion for at night may be heard of either in a Tavern, French-houſe, Conſtables hands, or the Counter.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Well; and is not that better then to be troubl'd with a formal fopp of bus'neſs, who lodges his wife in the Countrey, to preſcribe for the Agne, then ſcratches his empty Noddle, cryes, I proteſt I muſt poſt to London, I ſhall be undone elſe; there ſtayes a whole Term a doing nothing, or what is as bad, that which comes at laſt to nothing.

sp.speaker: Townl.
sp.p: And thinks he performs his Duty very well to his Wife, if he gives her a bout every poſt with a long formal Letter of Excuſes for not coming.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: VVhich muſt beget another on her full of Complaints, for his abſence.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Then when he returns in the Spirit of Beef and Ale, Will, it may beget a Male Child.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Which proves like the Ingredients 'tis Compounded of, a fit Companion for Clowns, and of no uſe but to have his Name inſerted in long Indentures, Tripartite for Intaling, ſpecially that Earth that is near as ſenſible as it's Clod-pate owner.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: The drawing of this deed too is a new excuſe for coming to London, and ſeeing, as the learned have it, his Uncle.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: So, that in fine your man of bus'neſs loves to be thought to love bus'neſs, Courts bus'neſs, lyes with bus'neſs, and begets nothing but buſineſs, or things as dull as buſineſs; and, Lady, will you ſlight a Man that loves Wit, Mirth, and Burgundy, for this Animal, nonrationale.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I pray, Sir, where's the neceſſity for marrying either, do you think there is none but ſuch as cannot ſtay at home for their bus'neſs, or will not, for their Wine and Wenches?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Lady, have a care; that is my Province: Wenches! if you ſpeak irreverently of Wenches I am bound to ſtand up for them, and ſhall ſoon be provok't to ſay, that if my friend here, and ſome few others like him, could but reliſh the pleaſure of Wenching, you, and all the ill-bred honeſt Women in the Town might ſleep quietly, or waking, gnaw your Sheets without the help of a Song and Fiddle at your windows. VVenching, quoth a.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Merry, I ſee you, for your Wine, and your Friend for Wenches, are ſo well met, 'twould be pity to part you, and I am reſolv'd not to be ſo cruel; therefore aſſuring you I am not in haſt for a Husband, but can ſtay till a ſoberer grow; if there be none yet ripe, I leave you to your further Adventures.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Faith, no parting ſo. Strike up, and ſing the Chorus, Chor. Ah, what Charms have thoſe Eyes, &c.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Pray hold, my Brothers coming.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I am glad of it, ſince I cannot reclaim the Siſter from doting on Sobriety. I'le ſee what can be done on the Brother; go on.
Then ſpight of my ſelf, &c.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Merry, you're upon the Ramble, I ſee; what time of Night is it?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: About two, and fair Weather; who would lye ſpending this pleaſant time in a lazy Bed, and then riſe to fry all day in the Sun?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Why, did not Nature intend the Night for Reſt, ſeeming to draw Curtains about us, and the Day for Action, diſplaying the great producer of it, Light.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: This Philoſophy may ſerve well enough for one not in Love, but 'faith my Body is too combuſtible to endure two fires at once; Love, and the Sun: and therefore I drink at Night to ſlacken than within, and ſleep in the Day to avoid that without.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I ſee you would ſeem a Philoſopher too, to juſtifie the drinking as caus'd by your Love, but my Siſter will ſcarce believe you in that.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Yes, Brother, but I will; for I do believe 'tis Love; Love of drinking, I mean, that cauſes the fire within he complains of, and ſo he drinks on to quench it.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, the ſtreet may prove ſcandalous: Roſe, go, let 'em in.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Scandalous! if you mean to them, 'tis impoſſible; for they're as well known in the ſtreet as the Bell-man, and as duly expected by the Neighbour-hood to their Lodgings punctually to come home at break of day.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You ſay right, Madam; the Smiths, Shoo-makers, Pewterers, and Sadlers in our ſtreet have no meaſure to call up their Prentices by, but the noiſe of my Fiddles playing me to my Lodging.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: He tells you true, Madam; for they heard once he was going to remove, and in great fright call'd a Veſtry the next Lord's Day, where it was propos'd to make a Collection amongſt them to pay for his Lodging, on Condition he would ſtay.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes, faith, and a ſolemn preſent of ſaffron Cakes and Sack given to Townlove, to move me to it.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Come, Gallants, you may enter; but Mr. Muchland is not of my mind, to ſuffer it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Prethee why, Roſe; I know thou art not ſo cruel, but thou could'ſt find in thy heart ſometimes to let in a Friend later than this.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Sir, it muſt be with greater expectation of a ſober demeanour when they come in, then I could hope from you now.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Townlove, Roſe is a Perſon I much rely on, therefore prethee mannage the controverſie begun with her, whilſt I go and excuſe my ſelf to her Miſtreſs.
sp.stage: Ex. all but Roſe and Townlove.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: No, Sir, Arguments are in vain to me, I'm ſo poſſeſt that Love and Wine are inconſiſtent together, that I think I could dy rather then recant my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: And, Roſe, it may be in doing ſo, would'ſt be as ſolid a Martyr as many of thy Sex, who have, as they ſay, witneſſed with their Death, truths they no wayes underſtood, nor indeed lay half ſo obvious to their Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Well, Sir, will you pleaſe to come in; the noiſe that theſe Fiddles keep will allure more of you wandring Knights to enter, except the Door be ſhut.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: No, Roſe, thou and I will ſtand and guard the paſſage to this Inchanted Caſtle, where vil'd Matrimonical Love is purſu'd in theſe dayes of clearer light.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, you dare not enter into any Houſe, it ſeems, that is defil'd with Honeſty; if thoſe be your principles, you and I are not proper Sentinels for one place, being Souldiers of two oppoſite parties.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Why, Roſe, are you for no Love that is not bound by the ſpell of, To have and to hold, and the little Magick Circle of Gold, that Fools ſay, makes one of two Perſons as inconſiſtent, and different in their Natures, as the Stars that govern 'em; and as far aſunder in their inclinations, as they are from one another in place.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I am altogether for being particular in Love, or for not being in Love at all, though I confeſs 'tis no great matter, I think, for any other tye than mutual conſent.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Divine Roſe! if thou art not now, or haſt not been particular, as thou call'ſt it, already, then this free humour I'm afraid will make me thine in ſpight of all reſiſtance, and therefore dear Roſe, admit of a Treaty, in order to a ſtricter League.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Which will begin on your part with a breach of Articles concerning ſome former commerce; that Amity is like to continue long, whoſe firſt Foundation is broken Faith.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: No doubts, Roſe, but muſt be explain'd on both ſides, to prevent future miſtakes, I muſt know whether I am the firſt diſcoverer of your Territories, that I may the better rate the curioſity, you ſhall know the true cauſe of my leaving my former Traffick, and ſeeking out new Countries.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I am not ſo fond of the Alliance, as to ſpend time in the Treaty; and ſo farewell, if you will not come in.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Come in, ſayſt thou! I am ſo taken with thy humour, that I would follow thee, though it was to Church.
sp.stage: The Scene changes into the Houſe, where is Merry, Muchland, his Siſter Honour, and the Fiddles.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Well, I'le go and dreſs my ſelf, and then Ramble with you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Do ſo; this Brother of yours, Madam, is a very honeſt Gentleman, and I have greater hopes of him then I have of you.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, you have a great deal of Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why, good Madam, can you ſhew a juſt exception againſt my manner of Living?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, Sir, a thouſand, if it concern'd me, but I ſhall not need to take pains in particulars about a thing ſo remote.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Madam, I muſt tell you, there is more thanks due to me for this Viſit, then you ſeem to beſtow by your cold indifferency.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Thanks for breaking my ſleep!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: For breaking your ſleep, ſay you; marry, I hope to have your thanks for doing it before I dye, notwithſtanding your ſeeming ſober diſlikes of it now.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: For hope, 'tis an Eſtate entail'd upon Lovers and Fools. There is no diſpoſſeſſing them of it, and though I cannot certainly define by which of the Titles you hold, yet this for your comfort I can tell you, Fiddles, and crying Fire are much the ſame to me about two in the morning, and were I marry'd, I cannot certainly tell which I ſhould ſooner wiſh my Husband ſhould waken me with.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, let your Servant wake you with Fiddles, and your Husband with Fire; the firſt provokes Dancing, the Emblem of Love, that never lets a man reſt, and the other is hot, and therefore requires a — Cooler.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Townlove, I thank thee for that—'tis the firſt time I e're heard thee ſpeak for ſitting up late; ſure thou haſt been drinking ſince I left thee without, thou art ſo thoughtful, nothing but Wine would have made thee arrived to the tenth part of this good Nature.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: No, truly, Sir, I have been loving, and loving a great deal for ſo little time.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: The fire of thy Love is like that of Gun-powder, flaſh, noiſe, ſmoak, and Exit. Mine is kindled in heart of Oak, where 'tis laſting and uſeful.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: And which to preſerve the Block the longer, you quench every Night by drenching it in Liquor, and then with a great deal of puſſing and blowing you kindle it again by Noon.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: And is not that well, when you can have half the day to warm your ſelf by it? an't would but hold out at that rate I ſhould prove the beſt Husband in Town; but faith, Madam, take me before I waſte too much, for this keeping the fire-light all Night will conſume fewel monſtrouſly.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: And 'tis two to one we ſhall ſit blowing our fingers half the long Winter of Marriage, for that's a cold time, I have heard many of you Gallants ſay.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Ay, ſuch as Townlove here, that know no other way to heat themſelves but at the main fire. But we that practice the warm Exerciſe of Drinking, never go cold to Bed, and a warm Bed-fellows Arms is a pleaſant place I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, I am ready for your commands now, let's whither you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why then, let's to your Miſtreſs, and ſerenade her, and call Ned Roſh her Brother up, and go to the Roſe Tavern for a Bottle of Burgundy.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I'le bring you on your way, till you go embarque for drinking, and then I'le take leave, being not willing to grow Sea-ſick to Night.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Brother Muchland, that muſt be, for ſo I know the Deſtinies have decreed; this Townlove is a very honeſt fellow, did he not delight in lewd Company.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: One good turn is, the faults of my Company are not ſo viſible, nor do not make ſuch a noiſe as yours do.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
If thou underſtoodſt noiſe, thou would'ſt not ſay ſo, for is't not the whole noiſe of the Town; who's ſuch a ones Miſtreſs, what he allows her, and whether ſhe has any certainty ſettl'd on her, or muſt upon diſlike be caſt off, and according to the anſwers of theſe
Queries ſhe is more or leſs reſpected, and makes the greater noiſe at her Lodgings in the Park, and at the Play Houſe.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: And good reaſon too; 'tis not the drinking of Wine, but your ability to pay for it makes you welcome to the drowſie Vintner at two in the Morning; and let the preciſe ſay what they will, 'tis plain they ne're complain of the ſins they themſelves get by, or delight in.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, you are in the right, I ne're heard of a Vintner or Bawd that complained of Drinkers or Wenchers, except they broke Windows, or built Sconces, and I'le aſſure you I have known very devout People of both thoſe Employments.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No doubt on't, People that would not have failed being at Church before the Pſalm was ſung for their Sundayes Dinner.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Truly it is the ſame in more warrantable Employments, for you ſhall never hear the Parſon ſpeak againſt the ſin his Patron is notoriouſly guilty of, or if he is forc't to Name it, it is in ſuch a whiſper, that few, except the Reader, can hear him.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Your Lawyer ne're ſpeaks againſt the forgery he is retain'd for; your Doctor, ne're againſt the cauſe of the Pox, nor will a Souldier be perſwaded there is any hurt in plundering.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Nor will all the Rhetorick a man has be enough to Convince a Tradeſman that he doth ill when he over-reaches them moſt that truſt him moſt.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Then ſince no Action, be it good or bad, but hath it's vouchers, I am for letting every one have his humour, and only beg that I may have mine, which terminates alwayes in the conſent of the parties I deal with, and the Devils in't if there can be harm in that, to which all Perſons concern'd give their approbation.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why, thou'rt in the right, Townlove, and therefore let us by mutual conſent purſue our intentions.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: What, call up a Lady with a noiſe of Fiddles at two in the morning, for no other purpoſe but to break her ſleep; it ſhall never be ſaid Townlove was partaker in ſuch a Crime; therefore you that can Dance, ſhall; and you that cannot, ſhall try; for I will have my frolick.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p:
And good reaſon you have for it, Sir, for 'tis a ſhame that thoſe who are ſo us'd to Dance about the ſtreets all Night ſhould be
able to do nothing tending to the ſame ſtirring faculty within Doors.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Then to your bus'neſs; firſt, the Catch in commendation of the Liberal Art of Wenching, and then a Dance, to ſhew the methodical motion of Reeling.

div.head: Catch.
div.l: 1. Boy, call the Coach; come, Jack, let's away:
'Tis tedious to ſit out this Tragical Play.
A Plague o'their pletting and dying in Rhime,
Let's drive to the Park
Before it be dark,
There we'l better diſpoſe of our Time.
2. Stay, who is that ſo dreſt like a Queen?
1. 'Tis the fine Lady Lofty, but let's not be ſeen:
For her Husband is ſurely gone out.
— She ſearches to find

l.hi: If a Friend will be kind,
And treat her abroad with a Supper and 'bout.

div.l: 2. Why ſhould ſhe want that? Her Lords a brave Man.
1. Ay, Jack, but they're marry'd.
2. Then what two are you?
1. 'Tis Will Lovewell and his pretty Miſs,
He hath kept her this ſeven year, yet prethee, Jack, ſee

l.hi: How jocund and merry they be,
How Crown'd, and incircl'd with Bliſs.
Love Revels, and Feaſts in hearts that are free,
But languiſhing ſtarves if reſtrained he be.

div.l: 1. See, yonder ſits Well-born with his pretty Wife.
2. They look as they'd ne're ſeen each other before.
1. Shee ſeeks for her Gallant, and he o'my Liſe

l.hi: Hath a mind to be feaguing you Vizor-Mask-Whore.
But ſtay, let me ſee; by Heav'ns 'tis ſo,
That Mask hides a Lady I know,
Who ſeems for to dote on Husband and Honour,

div.l: But look there, Ned Ranter has juſt fixt upon her.
2. She hath yielded, and ſee they do go.
1. If Wives will do this,

l.hi: Give me the true Miſs,
She'd be hang'd e're ſhe'd ſerve a Man ſo.
They're Fools then that Marry, and ſtrive to conſine
In politick Chains what ſtill will be free;
No Fetters can hold a pow'r that's Divine,
Nor Shackles reſtrain great Loves Deity.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What would I give, Roſe, to be a man but one Night, to ſee what pleaſure there is in the inſide of a Tavern; for ſure, it muſt be ſomething extraordinary maks Mre. Merry ſo continually delight in being there.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, it is not hard to compaſs your wiſh.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What, to be a man for a Night?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Ay, to be a man as far as amounts to carry on the deſign of going to a Tavern; for I believe theſe honeſt good fellows never examine the inſide of every mans Breeches that keep 'em Company.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Roſe, you are a little too wanton.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Madam, you are a little too preciſe; why, 'tis the bus'neſs of a Chamber-Maid to give hints of delight to her Lady when they are alone, and there is not one in ten, let them ſay what they will, but are pleas'd to hear ſomething to the purpoſe ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Now out upon thee; I am afraid Mr. Townlove and you have had a conference lately, you are ſo apt to change my innocent diſcourſe of a Tavern to matters nearer his purpoſe, in which I'le aſſure you I am not at all curious.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Well then, Madam, let that alone, and as to your obſerving the delights of a Tavern, I can put you in a way immediately to do it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What, without being known!

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; for the Suits, Perriwiggs, Hats, and Swotds that are to go to your younger Brothers into the Countrey, came home laſt Night, and your Brother has not ſeen them I am confident, if you and I put them on, we ſhall never be ſuſpected for any other then a couple of tight Bully Bocks.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: But ſhould we in this Habit intrude into their Company, I am afraid they'l make us drink, and I am not able to do that.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: But I am, Madam, I'le warrant you as far as a Bottle or two, and you may put on Mr. Townlove's humour, at which I'le Quarrel, and that ſhall be our Excuſe for leaving them before they agree to part.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Well, faith, I'le venture, for I long to ſatisfie my Curioſity.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Come, let's make haſte to dreſs our ſelves.
sp.stage: The end of the firſt Act.

div.head: The Second Act.
div.stage: Enter Muchland, Townlove, Merry, Fiddles, and Torches.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: STrike up, Boys, ſound Alarm to the ſleepy Sentinels of this Fortification.
Ah, what Charms have thoſe Eyes, &c.
sp.stage: They follow and make a noiſe.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: What, ſober Mr. Muchland! I little ſuſpected to have ſeen you at the head of a Troop of Fiddles and Torches, ſcowring of the Streets, and beating up of Quarters at ſuch a time of Night.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: You ſee how pow'rful Example is, yet conſidering theſe honeſt Gentlemen, my Companions, I think this may be as becoming an Exerciſe, as the following a pack of Doggs all day ſo hard, to kill my Horſes, and the Quarry only a rank Fox, for the noiſe of thoſe we Hunt, which now is much more Muſical.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come, come, dreſs, dreſs, we are in great haſte, and have much bus'neſs to do before that great make-bate, the Sun, who lights your Lawyers, Uſurers, Scriveners, Merchants, and other formal fopps to go together by the Ears, do riſe.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I am afraid we have diſturb'd your Siſter with our noiſe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Prethee, dear Muchland no fears, for let her be diſturb'd as much as ſhe will, ſhe'l take it for a ſign of Love, to ſee that when her Servant is Rambling, he cannot chooſe but take her in his way, and let them never ſo much diſlike the man that doth it, there was never one of them yet that was diſpleas'd at being belov'd.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I am of your mind, Mr. Merry, they are the ſame in Lovers as they are in Footmen, ſo they have but enough to wear the Livery, they deſire but one to do the bus'neſs, and glory more in the Manies conſtant attendance, then they do in the ones ability for performing their How de's.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Faith, Raſh, thou art i'th right; for till this way came up of keeping Miſſes, a Woman counted it a ſcandal to have but one Servant; 'tis true, they admitted them under the Name of Platonicks, Friends, or Admirers, but would oblige them at the charge of their Lovers or Husbands, rather then loſe their Viſits; but ſince this impropriating of Womens Fleſh without Matrimony came in requeſt, 'tis counted a greater diſgrace amongſt themſelves to admit of two Gallants, then e're it was for a marry'd Woman to Cuckold her Husband. And Opinion being the ſole Governour of mens Actions; I believe this to be the only way to introduce Chaſtity into the Female Sex again, and to ſecure men in the knowledge of their own Children.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I never knew you want an Argument to juſtifie Wenching in my Life. But come in, and I'le Dreſs me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Sound a Charge, and Enter.

div.stage:
Enter Ruffle, Tullam, and Breef,
• s from Play •• with a Drawer; Ruffle with ſome Dice in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sir, ne're tell me o'that, Sir, you're 〈◊〉 of Cheats, and I'le have my money again, or I'le ſo ſwinge you.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Good Mr. Ruffle conſider this Gentleman as a meer Stranger to me, and that money I have won of you, I have it fairly, and will keep it too in ſpight of your coun •• rf • it Courage.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Conſpiracy; a meer Conſpiracy, what t •• Devil, is not here a Dye hath nothing but fives upon it: here another with two ſixes, and there a third with two Quaters, and two •• e's? I tell you 'tis a plain Conſpiracy, and I will have my money again.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Sir, you know I am a meer Stranger to him, and met you at the Coffee-Houſe by chance, and truly, conſidering I have loſt all my money I might ju •• ſuſpect.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Suſpect, ha, what would you ſuſpect? ha!

Suſpect, Sir, look you, if you go to that, Sir, I might ſuſpect, 〈◊〉 that you drew me hither, and conſpir'd together to get my 〈◊〉 , Sir, 〈◊〉
••• eting thoſe Dice I ſee there, that I might ſuſpect, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sirrah, thou Varlet, darſt thou talk thus to a Gentleman of my Quality, that can ſpend a thouſand pounds per annum, and be ne're the worſe, that ever I ſhould light into the Company of a Slave that ſpunges at Ordinaries upon the winning hands for his Bread: begs to go ſix pence upon 7, to 5, and being broke by paying Laundreſs, or Lodging, ſets up again with a new borrow'd half-Crown.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Good Mr. Ruffle, be more civil; you know I brought you into the Houſe a Guinney, ſixteen ſhillings in ſilver, and a ſtuddle Watch-Caſe, and Chain, and have loſt them all; then me-thinks you might give me leave to ſpeak for my money.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Oh, Impudence! Drawer, what's to pay?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Three pounds, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Lok you there, Raſcal! is't likely you ſhould be ſet by us to get the value you ſpeak of; when the Reckoning comes to more. Thou Dogg, I have loſt fifty Guinneys, beſides three pounds in ſilver; and you come in with your ſtuddle Watch-Caſe and Chain, and we should deſign upon you in the Devil's name; very likely.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Sir, I have more money ſomewhere, and I believe all this heat is becauſe I had no more about me to loſe.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Damn'd Raſcal, doſt provoke me? I'le kick thee up the Chimney.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, pray, Sir, 〈◊〉 , what de'e mean, Sir? we ſhall talk about this anon.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Hold, Mr. Ruffle, this is not fair, nor muſt be here; we will have no Quatrelling, if I can help it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I vow to Gad, Mr. Fullam, you are a civil Gentleman, but there is no enduring of this Rogue; therefore, prethee give me leave to kick him out of the Company.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p:
No, Sir, that need not, Sir; on Condition you'l threw
thoſe Dice out of the Window, I'le borrow five Guinneys of the Drawer, and loſe them too, if it be my ill Fortune; but I'le aſſure you I'le look to the Dice we play with.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Well then; Drawer, go to your maſter, and bid him ſend me twenty Guinneys.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I ſhall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: And do you hear? bring me five.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: It ſhall be done, Sir.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: I proteſt, Mr. Ruffle, I am ſorry I have offended you; for you know 'tis not my cuſtome to Quarrel at the Ordinary, or any where elſe, but loſe my money as quietly as men of better Eſtates do.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Then this Fullam is a Rogue; but 'ſore Heaven, if I take him at his tricks, I'le cut's Ears off, or have my money again.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: You have reaſon; but Gad, I have ſome Tools here about me, as good Lows and Highs as e're ran on ſmooth Table; Gad, you might, and you would ſerve him a trick for his trick.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: And will, by Heaven; lend me them then.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: There, Sir, theſe are Lows, and theſe are High runners; you'l never find more than threes run on theſe, nor leſs than fours on theſe.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Then we'l to paſſage.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Come, Sir, let's into our Room, and ſeem angry ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: What advantage have men of Courage over Cowards; how tame this Rogue is with his beating? I have got ſome Reputation for my money in huffing this Rogue.

div.stage: Enter Merry, Muchland, Betty, Raſh, and Maid in Night Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Madam, you ſee the Excellencies of theſe Fellows: Was not the Sport you have had worth waking for?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes, truly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Faith, Madam, I never do worſe than this; my Bottle,
Fiddle, and Friend, are the Delights of my Life, and had not Cupid watch't a time when I was ſober, and ſhot me as I ſtood muſing on this Gentleman's Siſter, I think I ſhould never have thought of other pleaſures; but now ſpend at leaſt two hours in the twenty four, in muſing, ſighing, hoping, wiſhing, and fearing.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: A grievous affliction I'le aſſure you, Sir; and if I were able to perſwade the Lady that has this intereſt in your heart two hours of the day, ſhe ſhould e'en releaſe her part for altogether; for I think the twelfth part of a Man's heart is no more worth keeping then the twelfth part of a ſhilling, a ſum too little to be beſtow'd on the meaneſt Beggar.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, you ſpeak of a heart that can be divided; but alas, 'tis not ſo in mine; ſhe has right of common in the whole, every part is as much hers as any part, and ſhe can incloſe it when ſhe pleaſes, being Lady of the Mannor.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: But I am afraid you'd ſoon break down the Fences, and plead a preſcription of Liberty, eſpecially to that part that lyes neareſt the Water-courſe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What, a Lover! and in the preſence of his Miſtreſs, yet plead for the Adverſe party! O, Monſtrum Horrendum!

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, a whole Lover may have Liberty to ſpeak againſt the twelfth part of one, there is no proportion between e'm.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis poſſible the twelfth part of one heart may be more then the whole of another.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Faith, Brother Mushland, I think there you are met with.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I ſhould be loath to think the Lady meant a compariſon between your heart and mine; but if ſhe did, I would be glad ſhe would take the trouble of ſurveying both before ſhe gave final Judgment in ſo difficult a cauſe.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Since I pretend a Title to neither, nor know any body that doth, you ſhall pardon me if I concern not my ſelf about the Buts, Bounds, Quantity, or Quality of the premiſes.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Madam, you that command ſo many hearts, you think to deſcend to the obſervation of particulars is below you; but ſince you will at laſt find it convenient to Build, you ought to ſurvey well the place you intend to ſit down upon.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p:
Sir, you ſay well; and when I begin to think of that, I ſhall
not fail to be very circumſpect in my Choice.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: But do it quickly, Madam, Life's ſhort, and if you intend to enjoy the fruit your ſelf, you muſt plant betimes.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Madam, this Brother of yours is more circumſpect in dreſſing himſelf for the Tavern, then Mr. Muchland was to come to his Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: It is a ſign he has a greater reſpect for the one, then Mr. Muchland has for the other.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Nay rather, Madam, impute it to the exceſs of my deſires, which prompted me to ſuch haſte, as I regarded nothing but the hopes of ſeeing you.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Come, let's away to the Roſe, for 'tis almoſt Day; and 'tis more ſcandalous to enter a Tavern, then come out of one in a Morning.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: 'Tis true, had not we the laudable excuſe of Fiddles and Link-Boys, which are infallible ſigns of no early Riſers.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Well, all the Good Fellows we meet in the Street, and all that are in the Tavern are part of our Company, know e'm, or know e'm not.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Provided, they carry good Teſtimony that they riſe not thus early about bus'neſs, for if we meet any ſuch, they or we muſt change ſides of the way.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Ne're fear it, Gentlemen, ſuch, if they meet you, will give you the way without Quarrelling; for if you look on e'm as Fools, they think as ſure that you are Mad-men.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: And with very good reaſon; and therefore, deſiring I may be ſuſpected for one of theſe fooliſh Men of bus'neſs, I beg Liberty to give way to you Men of the Moon-light.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Be but a Mad-man to the Tavern, Townlove, and then go away like a Fool if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Well, come on then; I will endure worſe denominations then theſe, ſo I may but have my humour.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come, Rogues, Raſcals; come away, and ſound a retreat to Mr. Muchland, who ſcarce marches off with flying Colours as I did from my Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p:
Sir, I dare ſay he is no more without nopes then you are
without Confidence.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: No, Madam, in ſpight of Mr. Merry, I will not believe my ſelf ſo miſerable, as to be paſt all hopes.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Faith, Mr. Muchland, nor need not, if it be'nt your own fault.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Fie, Brother.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Fie, Siſter; I'le tell thee, Muchland, ſhe's more afraid of being forſaken, then you are of being ſlighted.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I dare not think my ſelf ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: You are a Fool then, let her deny what I ſaid, if ſhe can.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Brother, this is unſufferable.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Come, come, prethee come away, there is ſuch fooling and diſſembling with theſe Women.
sp.stage: Exeunt all but Betty and Maid, with Fiddles playing before e'm.

sp.speaker: Bet,
sp.p: This Brother of mine has ſo throughly vex'd me, by diſcovering my inclination, that I ſhall not be able to ſleep for thoughts of it.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Why ſhould you be troubl'd, Madam, ſince me-thinks 'tis well he knows it, 'twill put an end to the bus'neſs quickly.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: But if he ſhould ſlight me, I believe I ſhould dye.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Ne're fear that, Madam, you have him too faſt.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Come, I will to bed; no more this Morning.

div.stage: Entes at one Door, Muchland, Townlove, Merry, and Raſh: At the other, Honour and Roſe in Men's Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Stand, who goes there?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Ah, Roſe, 'tis they!

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: No matter; what are you that queſtion who we are in ſuch high Terms?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Are you men of buſineſs? For if you be, you muſt leave this ſide of the Street clear to us.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, do you think we look like perſons that are ſent
to fetch Doctors, Apothecaries, or Midwives thus early; or, that we riſe this Morning not to fail meeting at ſome zealous brothers, for the Spiritual comforts of a morning Lecture; no faith, we are men of no more bus'neſs then your ſelves.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Are you Good Fellows, or Wenchers, that you are upon the Ramble ſo late?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Partly t'one, partly to'ther, like moſt of Mankind; but by what Authority do you examine us thus?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: We have a Commiſſion to take up all ſtragglers we meet, and carry them to the Roſe Tavern.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Where, after Drinking all Night, you intend to take your Mornings Draughts; is't not ſo?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: 'Tis true, that's the ſcope of our Commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: We are for you then, though my friend here never Drinks; he's for pleaſures of another Nature.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I have Commiſſion to Diſpence him as well as my ſelf, he being I find of our Brigade.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Fall into your places then.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: But not ſo eaſily I believe, you will think we did not deſign to play the Philoſophers: No, we are for mirth and madneſs, frolicks of ſome noiſe muſt tempt us to engage in your Company, elſe we are going to thoſe that know truly how to be merry; men of mettle, that though they will not break Laws, have an Art of ſtretching of e'm as far as the beſt pleading Caſe Lawyer that wears a Coif —

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: And that is further by half then any Shoo-maker can his Leather; for they can fit Law to every Laſt.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Therefore in plain terms, Gentlemen, we muſt ſee ſome frolick perform'd that will convince we are not like to loſe precious time in your Company, or we ſhall take you for ſome Conſtables, Church-wardens, Sides-men, and Over-ſeers in Diſguiſe, a going to Ferret, and ſet Toils for the tame Game of Whetſtone's Park.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Your ſcruples of Conſcience are ſo weighty, there ought to be much care taken to ſolve the doubts.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Your Company ſeems ſo good, that let the Conditions be but poſſible on which we are to gain your acquaintance they ſhall be perform'd: What ſay we, ſhall we break Windows, pull down Signs, beat Conſtables, or fire the Church —

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Hold! Fire Coven-Garden Church; Heav'n forbid! If that ſhou'd once be done, then ſhou'd I be condemn'd never to hear Common-Prayer again.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: And what a loſs would that be to the Church, to have ſuch a Pillar remov'd?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Coven-Garden Church! It is the Theatre of Beauty, and Rendevouz of Miſſes and Gallants. I dare avow 'tis a greater Advantage to Love's Empire then both the Play-houſes are. No, I'le have no firing of Coven-Garden Church in my Company; any other Church in the Kingdome I think may be ſpar'd.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: No, Gentlemen, theſe ſort of frolicks we are not for; there's no venturing upon ſuch without the ſecurity of as many Lives as a Cat; beſides, we hate to be giving the lye to Reverend Men of the long Robe, in crying not guilty, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Invent, invent then! What is't we muſt do?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Can you Dance all of you? The place is convenient here within the Piazza.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: We can do ſomething like it, moſt of us.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I wiſh we had but a Bell then; we would wake all the People of the Piazza, and ſhew e'm by our mirth, the difference between Living as we do, and dying; that is, Eating, Drinking, Sleeping, and Melancholy moving to no purpoſe, as they do.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: We ſhall but loſe time in looking for a Bell-man, and I have a Trumpet here will make a greater noiſe; I carry it alwayes with me, to ſound at ſome particular Healths.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: That will do much better, the rarity of it will beget more attention.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come then, a Levite; my Man here has a Speech to go round with: I uſe it at my Friends Windows as I Ramble to my Lodgings a Mornings.
Come, I'le ſpeak it firſt at this Corner my ſelf, and then he ſhall about with it, whilſt we fall to our Dance.

q.l: GRave ſober Sots riſe from your Beds,
And juſt thruſt out your Logger-heads,
With Eyes half ſhut, and ſenſes dull'd
You'l ſee a little how you're gull'd,
And kept from pleaſures of the Dark,
By precepts wiſe of Lamb and Lark.
But learn by us your Lives to mend,
For Life is ſhort, and time will end:
And when you're dead, for what you do,
Your merry Heirs will laugh at you.

sp.p: Morrow Mr. Scrape, Morrow Mrs. Scrape, Morrow Mr. Save-all, Morrow my Lord Sober, Morrow my Lady Penſive, Morrow Mr. Catch-good: Morrow, you Sleepers all, good Morrow.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Stand upon your Guard, Gentlemen, the Conſtable and Watch are coming.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Let e'm come, I have a ſure way to keep ſuch Dogs from Barking, as can be; if our party be two ſtrong, they flye off courſe; but if not, I take him by the hand, and cry good Mr. Conſtable don't you know me? Strait with the help of their horns they peep in my face, whilſt he has time to conſider that he is richer by half a Crown then he was; then, as in an extaſie of Joy, he crys, ha, Sir, is it you? Will you have any of my Watch wait on you? Which I denying, we part with as many farewells, and good wiſhes to one another, as if we had tumbl'd together in one Belly, though it may be we ne're ſaw one anothers faces before.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Stand, who goes there?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No body.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What, are all you no body?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I ſay, no body goeth here, for we are all ſtanding.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: You are merry Gentlemen, but I ſhall alter your humour preſently; come before the Conſtable one of you, keep the Peace in the Kings Name, keep the Peace, I am his Majeſties Conſtable. Oh, I ſhall be kill'd, I am a dead Man: Oh, my Wife and Children: I'le have you all hang'd if I be kill'd: I ſay, keep the Peace; in the King's Name, keep the Peace.
sp.stage: They all advance with their ſwords drawn, and away run the Watch.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What, Mr. Laſt, is't you?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p:
Ay, an't pleaſe your Worſhip, your Worſhips own Shoomaker;
good Sir, don't uſe me ill, your Worſhips ſhooes are ready for you.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Uſe thee ill! What, my man of mid-night! Do'ſt think we'l uſe thee ill? How does thy Wife and Daughter Joan? they are pretty Rogues both.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Townlove, you are pleas'd to ſay ſo, but 'tis your goodneſs more then their deſert truly; though indeed they alwayes talk of your Worſhip, and are near falling out ſometimes about you, in arguing which loves you beſt, but I to keep the Peace part them, and take my Daughters part, becauſe poor thing! My Wife is her Mother in Law, I hope your Worſhip will not be angry at it —

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: No, no, Mr. Conſtable, by any means keep the Kings Peace within doors, it will keep it ſelf without.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Laſt, how many Priſoners have you that are not able to pay Ranſom? I am reſolved to Act the Juſtice, and ſet all at Liberty after due Examination.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Why truly, Sir, we have only took four Gentlewomen, which we were carrying to the Round-houſe; I'le make the Watch bring e'm before your Worſhip — Bring the Priſoners.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come, Madam, turn up your head, and let's ſee your face very well! What is your employment?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Prethee Merry, be not impertiennt, what ſhould a pretty Womans employment be? Let me ſpeak to her; Come, Madam! fear nothing if you tell Truth: Are you a Park, Play-Houſe, or Street-plyer? Do you Live upon Induſtry, or are you kept?

sp.speaker: 1. Wom.
sp.p: I am kept, Sir.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: What makes you out at this time of Night?
This may be my own caſe.

sp.speaker: 1. Wom.
sp.p:
I am kept by one that allows me but forty ſhillings a week, and makes at leaſt ten Guinneys of me; for he bargain'd I ſhould admit any Friend of his, and he brings almoſt every day a new one, and ſometimes two or three, with whom he keeps ſo good Intelligence, that whatſoever they give me, I can never ſink a ſingle ſhilling for Coach-hire; he ſometimes lets me out too, as it happen'd this Night, to a Country Parſon, whoſe Land-lady ſuſpecting the matter, and Jealous of loſing any thing her ſelf, turn'd me out
of doors without a penny of Money, ſo I fell into the Watches hands, and I hope, ſince you ſeem a civil Gentleman, you will redeem me, for it will be very injurious to my Honour to go to the Round-houſe.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Thy Honour ſhall be as ſafe as a Thief in a Mill, ne're fear it; Come, Madam! Your Quality.

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.p: My buſineſs lyeth altogether in the City, Sir; for I find them the beſt Cuſtomers.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But how ſtruck you into that Trade?

sp.speaker: 2. Who.
sp.p: Truly, by meer chance, Sir; for ſitting one day in Maſque at the Play-houſe, in the middle Gallery, ſome Clerks began to talk wildly to me, till an Ancient, Grave Man, who proved ſince to be a Packer to Merchants, rebuk'd them, and ſaid, their Diſcourſe was ſinful; then giving me a tread on the Toe, and a pinch on my Arm, went out; I follow'd him, hoping he'd prove lucky, and ſo he did, for beſides his own bounty, he hath brought me acquainted with ſo many Rich Citizens, that I have more work then I can turn to, though I confeſs they being moſt Old, I have diſpatch'd half a ſcore ſometimes in a day.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But after your abundance of Trading at that, how came you to this end of the Town?

sp.speaker: 2. Who.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I Love a Young Gentleman that I keep, whom I came to ſee, and having given him all the money I had, I was going back to turn the penny.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: A very honeſt, induſtrious Woman this, ſhe ſhall have no harm: Come, let's ſee, what's your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: 3. Who.
sp.p: You ſha'not ſee my Face, I'le go to Priſon ſooner:

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ſhe's a ſtubborn Jade, and call'd me Cuckold.

sp.speaker: 3. Who.
sp.p: And ſo you are one, to uſe poor Women thus: Mr. Town-love, let me ſpeak with you — 'Tis I —

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Truly, Mr. Laſt, I think ſhe ſpeaks to the purpoſe in calling of you Cuckold, for this uſage ſhe ſhall not ſhew her Face. Will Merry, 'tis his Wife.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: The Devil 'tis; 'twas lucky then we met, or how would ſhe have got off.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p:
She'd have ſaid it was to watch his haunts ſhe came abroad, or ſome ſuch thing — ſhe would have tam'd him quickly, for 'tis
a very Devil of her Tongue, and Cuckolds him almoſt before his Face.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Well, who are you?

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: A very good Gentlewoman both born and bred; I am a Presbyterian Miniſters Daughter.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A ſubſtantial Title to Gentility, who will ſay after this the Crown is the Fountain of Honour, when they that pull'd it down can make Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: 'Tis poſſible her own Employment doth mote entitle her to it, therefore let's know that.

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: Sir, I have had a great mind to be a Player, and have offer'd my ſelf to both Houſes, and truly moſt of the ſharers have had me ſeverally at their Chambers to try me, and they all ſay, I do very well; but 'tis the Envy of the Women already there, that fearing I ſhould out-do e'm, keep me out, as I was told by two or three of the hired men of the Duke's Houſe, with whom I have been to Night, and ſpent all my money, but I do not doubt to find Friends to bring it about, for there are two or three Perſons of Quality have undertaken it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nay, then there's no fear of ſucceeding.

sp.speaker: 4. Wom.
sp.p: No, I hope not; alas, I deſire little or nothing for my pains, I would only ſhew my ſelf on the Stage, and then, perhaps, I may get a good Husband, or at leaſt, ſome Fool that will keep me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Honeſt good Women all; and are not you hard-hearted to diſturb the Lawful endeavours of ſuch well-minded People, Mr. Conſtable — Well, there are Reſolutions taken by ſome Gentlemen of my Acquaintance to make you keep cloſer to your Lawful buſineſs — which is indeed to cry Fire, prevent Houſe-breaking, and ſnore on Stalls according to your primitive inſtitution, and not to ſet to Ranſom, or Impriſon People induſtriouſly improving the two great works of Whoring and Drinking. War is declar'd, and ſhall be carry'd on againſt all the Obſtructions of Trade, as you ſhall hear in a Song lately publiſh'd, in which all muſt bear their parts.

div.head: Song.
div.l: 1. THe Trade of wine is much decay'd of late;
The Vintners complain, and the Cuſtoms abate,
For Pickaroon Bill-man in every Street,
Like Capers make prize of all Traders they meet.
2. Come then, 'tis time to ſcowr alongſt the Coaſt;
To re-take good Fellows, who elſe may be loſt:
'I is Lawful thoſe Foes to invade,
Who rob us of Honour, and hinder our Trade;
And a damn'd Zealous Conſtable 'midſt of his Watch-men
Does Trading more harm, then a Squadron of Dutch-men;
1. Weigh Anchor then, and hoiſt up Sail;
Nore and by Weſt it blows a merry Gale.
2. The Glaſs is run, ho, ſtar-board, Watch, turn out;
Heark, did you hear, that Gun was from a Scout.
Run to the top,
3. Hey Boys, I ſee a Fleet,
They bear hard up to us; we quickly ſhall meet.
1. All hands to prayers, and make ready to fight,
2. You need not, their Flags are all white;
That Colour denotes them for Wine or a Wench;
All Half-ſhirts are for us, as ſure as the French.
They hale our Scouts, me-thinks I hear e'm call,
1. Whence your Fleet?
3. From White-Hall.
1. VVhence your Fleet?
3. From White-hall.
1. VVe are Friends to e'm, then cry, Huzza.
2. Once again, Huzza.
1. And again, Huzza.
3. They are Friends to us, then cry, Huzza.
3. Once again, Huzza.
3. Once again, Huzza.
4. And again, Huzza, huzza, huzza.
Now we are all met, let's draw into a Line;
Charge every man his Glaſs of VVine,
'Tis our Royal high Admirals Health,
VVhilſt we drink all Night,
He does Hero-like Fight,
To reſcue the Kingdoms Honour and VVealth.
Let Trumpets ſound, and all at once give Fire,
If the Enemy comes, we'l ſoon make e'm Retire.
1. Let's Charge them again, for a Health to the King.
2. They come, they come, their Bell-man does Ring.
3. Their Caps, Staves, and Lanthorns I ſpie,
They've horns in their Flags, and they bear e'm on high.
4. Fall on then, fall on, tan tara rara, &c.
1. They flye, they flye.
2. Then give a Broad-ſide, and cry, Vive le Roy, Vive le Roy.
2. Give the Broad-ſide, &c.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Now theſe four Gentlewomen will make our Dance the better.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come, to every Lady a Link and a Watch-man for ſafeguard to their Lodgings.

sp.speaker: 3. VVom.
sp.p: Except me, Sir, mine is not far off.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: 'Tis true, you ſhall only have one of my Links; Mr. Conſtable, no more Pris'ners to Night, as you tender my good Grace; and there's a Crown to Drink.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: VVe'l know no other Juſtice hereafter but your, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Now every one to their ſeveral abidings, and we for the Roſe, ſound a Charge, and let's aſſault the place.

div.head: The Third Act.
div.stage: Enter Ruffle, Breef, Fullam, and Drawer.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: COme, come, Sir, theſe are no Jeſting matters, I'le not be cheated of all my Money thus.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: How do you mean cheated, Mr. Ruffle?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: How do I mean? Did I not find a Dye with all Sinks, and others of the like Nature?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: I love you for that, I'faith, Mr. Ruffle, I hope you don't take me for a Cully.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Nor ſhall you make me one, if I can help it, and therefore, ſay, was there not ſuch Dice here? we'l find afterwards who brought e'm in.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: I ſaw no ſuch Dice, not I.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Nor I, I'le aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Hey day, here's fine Rogues; Drawer, did not you ſee the Dice I ſpeak of?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: No, Sir, not I; 'tis true, I heard you ſay ſome ſuch thing, but I could not believe Gentlemen would put falſe Dice upon one another.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: No, but Cheats will.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: How do you mean, Sir, I ſay? Cheat again! war the third time, Mr. Ruffle.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I ſay, this Gentleman and I are Cheated, and by you, that's plain, and if he'le be rul'd by me, you ſhan'not carry it off ſo.

sp.speaker: d Ful.
sp.p: I can endure no longer: Come, come, come, draw, raw, Sir, for I will have ſatisfaction for this abuſe.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I'le bear no witneſs.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Do you think to carry it off ſo?
sp.stage: All this while be baſt'es about, throws his Hat away, pulls off his Perriwig, and ſeems to be preparing to fight.
sp.p: Come, Sir, why don't you prepare? Do you ſee how he braves us?

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Wee'l beat him, take out money again, and then have him toſt in a Blanket.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: I ſhall not ſtain my Honour in being two againſt one.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I am croſs bit I ſee.

Nay, I can as well ſpare what I loſt, as you can yours, and it ſhall ne're be ſaid, I fought to recover anothers money, that would do nothing for it himſelf; give me your hand, Mr. Fullam, I am very glad 'twas your Fortune to get it, ſince it is mine to loſe it.

sp.speaker: Full.
sp.p: This is but trivial ſatisfaction, Sir, for the abuſes you have put upon me.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Hang't, Man, Paſſion, meer Paſſion; give loſers leave to ſpeak, I wou'd take twice as much for half the money, and I think I value my Honour as much as another (if I can but get off with Credit now.)

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I think you ſpeak Reaſon, therefore, pay the Reckoning, and we are Friends.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: How do you mean, Mr. Fullam? Have not you got all the money?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: And will keep it, Sir; therefore reſolve to pay the Reckoning, or —

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Plague on't, I ne're value three or four pounds; and it may be thou haſt particular occaſion for this ſum of money at preſent, then we'l ne're ſtand upon ſmall matters, I'le do't. But for you, Sir, I'le talk with you for your Highs and Lows.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Very pretty, i'faith, a well fram'd Dialogue: Good Mr. Ruffle, 'tis too plain; do you think your counterfeit Quatrels ſhall carry it off ſo? I ſhall ſtand by, and ſee my ſelf cheated of my meney, and take it kindly I have loſt it, becauſe you can Rally one another.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: What do you mean by this, Sir?

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Sir, you are a ſtranger to me, and I can't blame you for what you have done; but to be ſet and bubled by Mr. Ruffle, on pretence of Friendſhip, is unſufferable.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: What the Devil, is not one kicking enough for you in one Night? Muſt I be bound to wear out my ſhooes upon you?

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir, I know when to take a kicking, and when not. I bore with it then, in hopes you would have ſo mannaged the Dice I lent you, as to have won money for me, but on the contrary, you plac'd e'm upon our ſelves: therefore, Sir, refund, refund, I'le not loſe a groat of the money I loſt.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: But ſure you don't hope to carry it off ſo: Have I any of your money?

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: But your Friend hath for your uſe, and I'le look no further then your ſelf for it; therefore, my money, or Draw.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: 'Fore Heav'n this is pretty; then it ſeems you both deſign'd upon me.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Come, Sir, will you repay me?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Mr. Ruffle, here is a great many Gentlemen with Fiddles, hearing you were here, are reſov'd to come up to you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: What ſhall I do? Gentlemen, ſtep into another Room, I'le come and give you full ſatisfaction preſently.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I am content to wait a little.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: The Devils in my luck, I never get a little Reputation by beating a Man, but preſently ſome body or other huffs me out of it again, and then all my Honour flyes in Fumo. 'Tis true, I am a Coward, but no body need e're a known it but my ſelf, if I had not a fooliſh deſire to be thought valiant, and ſo muſt ſtill be picking Quarrels with all I think like my ſelf. And I gad, 'tis not once in twenty times, but I miſs my Man and get a beating.

div.stage: Enter Merry, Townlove, Raſh, Muchland, Honour, Roſe, and Fiddles.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What, Ruffle alone in a Tavern at four in a Morning, that's a thing I ne're was guilty of.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Come, come, Table and Chairs.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
Faith, Will Merry, to tell thee the truth, I have been
bubling a couple of Culleys to Night, and the poor things having loſt all their money are ſtaying for more in another Room.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Faith, that doth not uſe to be thy way, for I have known thee oſtner a Bublee then a Bubler.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: That's true, but when I grant out my Letters of Mart to my Highs and Lows, there's no Man ſooner takes in repriſal then I; and I'faith, they have been all at work to Night.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What have you won?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Let me ſee; fifty Guinneys, three pounds in ſilver, and twenty Guinneys more they borrowed of the Maſter of the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: And did they not ſmoak you, as their term is?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Yes, a little; but one of e'm beginning to prate, I kickt him ſoundly.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Thou Boy; now I believe nothing of the whole matter: Thou venture to kick a Man, 'tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Why, this 'tis, becauſe I am a little compliſant ſometimes, and put up injuries from Gentlemen, therefore, you, it ſeems, have mean thoughts of me, but you ſhall hear; come hither, Stephen.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Your pleaſure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Did not you ſee me kick a Gentleman ſoundly to Night for talking to me of Cheating?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I'le aſſure you, I was afraid you would hurt him.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: And was not there twenty Guinneys borrowed of your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; and five of me.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: That's true (go thy ways) law you now, I had forgot that five Guinneys.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Miracles, Miracles, Miracles, give us Wine there; Miracles are not ceaſt: Here's a Health to Ruffle's Converſion, Townlove; thou ſhalt pledge this, if thou never drink'ſt more.
sp.stage: All this while Ruffle ſtruts about.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, you muſt pardon me, if I don't know ſome great cauſe for it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Thy Ear.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, you know he is a merry Man every way, let him have his frolick: La, la, la, la, la, Sir, my Service to you, Will Merry's Health.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Sir, I drink no Wine.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Damme, not pledge me, Sir, 'fore Heav'n but you muſt, or I ſhall throw it in your face.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Good Sir, be not rude, the Gentleman has our word to excuſe him.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: If he hath your word, let him paſs it. la, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Sir, I commend it to you.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I never drink by Commendations, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Well done, Boy; here's another milk-ſop: What, can't he drink neither?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, or any thing elſe with you that you dare.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: 'Fore Heav'n a Lad of mettle; give me thy hand: Here's a health to all that dare, and a fig for men that dare not do any thing.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Sir, I'le pledge it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Some Wine, there; give every one of the Muſick a glaſs in his hand

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Mr. Ruffle, I congratulate the change, and if I have any intereſt in my Lady Turnup, ſhe ſhall be yours, ſince the onely obſtacle is remov'd.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Faith, Mr. Townlove, you ſee men will ſhew themſelves ſuch one time or other. 'Las, the ſtouteſt Bully Rock of e'm all ne're went to ſingle Rapier in ſwadling Cloaths, they had all a time to begin: La, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You are i'th' right, Mr. Ruffle; come, the Catch.

lg.l: 1. BOy, bring a Glaſs without marks, to confine
The Ebbs and the Floods of our Drinking;
Our Cups ſhall be heap'd with a full-tide of Wine,
Till our Tongues do ſpeak wit without thinking.
2. We will with Wines, Aetherial fire,
Like ſubtile Chymiſts, Bodies change;
That without words each mans deſire
Shall through the others fancy range.
1. Wine ſhall waſh off our Earthly parts,
And to new Creatures mold us;
2. We'l take off our Bouls,
Till we mingle our Souls,
And the World grows too little to hold us.

l.hi: We'l, &c.

lg.l: 1. All hands to work then, time ſlides away,

l.hi: Night chides our ſloath, and haſtens on the day;

lg.l: 2. Then the Sun will bring heat

l.hi: For our Limbeck ſo high,
And make our Elixar in fumo to flye.

lg.l: 1. Heark, do you hear, the Men cry Chimney ſweep;

l.hi: Fanatick Wives will now no longer ſleep;
Strange Dreams of Religion have wak'd e'm by this:
In heat of their zeal
They'l preſently rail
At every thing is, and is not amiſs.

lg.l: 2. Be ſure if they ſee us, of Cuſtom they'l ſay,

l.hi: We turn Day into Night, and Night into Day;

lg.l: 1. In this they are right;

l.hi: We'd turn Day into Night;
But they lye, if they ſay,
That we would e're wiſh to turn Night into Day.
In this, &c.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Bravely done, Boys; now to a little ſilent drinking: Townlove, you keep a good man from us.
sp.stage: During the Catch Townlove and Roſe talk together.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I'le releaſe him preſently.
Faith, Sir, you ſee I have open'd my heart to you, in hopes to make you my Friend, for there is ſomething in your face pleaſes me extremely.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to you by it, and ſhall as much ſeek to deſerve it; but me-thinks three hundred pounds a year is conſiderable to allow you Miſtreſs, if you pay it conſtantly.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p:
I never fail you may be ſure, whoſoever ſtays, ſhe muſt not. A dun between a pair of Sheets makes a man more impotent
then a Witches tying of a Countrey Fellows Cod-piece-point.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Well, Sir, for my own part, I never underſtood the pleaſure of keeping Miſſes, I'm for othermens, if for any.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I believe your Friend is not of your mind; he, I perceive by his refuſing to drink, is for his Miſs; can you let me know who ſhe is?

sp.speaker: Reſe.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I know of none he hath, he's Young, and rather talks of Marriage then Miſſes.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Why, there's the miſchief on 't; he's new come from the Univerſity, or I'le be hang'd; there's more of our hopeful Youth ſpoil'd by Schools and Univerſities then is imaginable; they learn nothing but to tread the dull paths of our Fore-Fathers, to bury themſelves alive in Marriage-Beds, to ariſe Monſters with huge Horns on their heads; if you have any kindneſs for him reclaim him from ſuch a deſign.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I have us'd my endeavours, and find him a little inclining to be kind to one Roſe, that waits on Mr. Muchland's Siſter.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Gad, Sir, I had rather he had a mind to be kind, as you call it, to my Siſter, and ſooner ſhould forgive him for it

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Why, Sir, what is ſhe to you?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: She's one I have a mind to, and am reſolv'd if three hundred pounds a Year will tempt her, ſhe ſhall be mine; provided, he, nor no other ſmock-fac'd Fellow hath been Quarter'd upon her afore hand.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: How'l you know that, if it is ſo?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: P'ſhaw, ne're ask queſtions of an Old Gameſter; and I'm reſolv'd, ſince my preſent Miſs is to be married, I'le purſue my deſign upon Roſe, to prevent yon ſmock-fac'd Fellow, of whom I have dreadful apprehenſions.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Well, Sir, trouble not your ſelf, I'le take care he ſhall remove his Siege.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Townlove, thou think'ſt we have nothing elſe to do but to talk; releaſe our man there, that you have taken Priſoner by the Ears.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Well, take him, but 'tis a thouſand pities he ſhould be ſpoyled by you.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I'le warrant you, Sir, I am paſt their ſpoyling.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I have perform'd my word with you; and ſo farewell.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Farewell; you have return'd us a better man for our preſent purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Sir, you're in a rear, and ſince you allow drinking to be your profeſſion, you muſt balance Accounts, and pay down what you owe.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I'le aſſure you, Sir, I am but juſt begun to be a profeſſor in the Myſtery, therefore, if you call for Debs too ſoon, you'l break me, and I ſhall ne're be able to follow the Trade, then let's now go on, I'le run in a rear no further, and the next time I meet you I'le balance Accounts.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Come, the Gentleman ſaith well, 'tis not our bus'neſs to be drunk, but to be merry; therefore, let's not break Methods at the preſent for any thing paſt.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: But, Mr. Muchland, by your leave I deſire no man to be a ſober obſerver of my drunken behaviour, therefore, if he and his Friend will not drink equally, I ſhould be glad of their rooms.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Sir, as I take it, it was your own fault you had our Companies, and the terms we met on were agreed to before.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Not by me, I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Nor by me, therefore if you won't drink, turn out of the Company.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt tell you this is rude, and no wayes becoming a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: How, Sir, what's that, Rude? La, la, la.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange to ſee how men can ſee others faults, and be blind to their own; you tell Mr. Ruffle he's Rude for ſpeaking in his own Room, into which you intrude to controul him.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Alas, alas, the Gentleman's lately come out of the Countrey, he doth not underſtand good breeding; la, la, la, poor thing.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Mr. Raſh, I can take more from you; but —

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: But what; out with it, I'm your man, ne're look at him, and I muſt again tell you, that I believe you want good manners ſo to controul; here I ſay, theſe Gentlemen ſhall drink, or quit the Room.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: And will, Sir, no fear; we do not at all hold our ſelves oblig'd by Quarrelſom Company: Drawer, what's to pay?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Gentlemen, nothing for you; I am ſorry to have engaged you thus inconveniently, I'le aſſure you 'tis rare for me to ſee theſe things, eſpecially amongſt Friends.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: We thank you, Sir, and all others from whom we have received Civility.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Damme, what's that, Civility? They deſerve to be kickt.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: What, by you?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I, by him; and 'tis not you can hinder it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: No, by Heav'ns is it not, nor two ſuch, dear heart.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir, if I ſhould tell you you lye, I'm afraid Mr. Raſh would call me rude, but I cannot forbear thinking ſo.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Sir, you provoke me to tell you, you're fit Company for Dogs and Horſes, and not for men, except 'tis your own Grooms, or'e whom you had beſt go and domineer in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir, you know my Obligations, or elſe —

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Or elſe what?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Or elſe what? Poor thing: Or elſe what prethee? La, la, la.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Or elſe that.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Damme, Blood, that; death and wounds, let me alone, nothing ſhall ſave him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Gad, Sir, be as Valiant as you will, I'le ſwinge you if you be not quiet.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Mr. Ruffle, the affront was meant to me; be quiet, Sir, we deſire no Quarrels here, and therefore you or I will quit the Room.
sp.stage: Walks to and again in a great Rage.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: You pretend a right to it by the intereſt of your huffing Friend, therefore I'le quit it, And the World too, rather then take this.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: — Sir, I'le ſee you at Home preſently. Mr. Ruffle, have you no body to Exerciſe your ſetting out towards Valour upon but my Friends?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Friend me no Friends, I know no Friends in point of Honour, that's it I'le ſtick to.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Then I muſt tell you, Sir, you and I muſt not part before
I carry my Friend ſatisfaction in your Blood, or loſe my own.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Will Merry, thou pretend'ſt to be a man of Honour, and place theſe things upon me, 'tis very well, I'faith, thou think'ſt now that I am not Valiant, and therefore pick'ſt a Quarrel, but it ſhannot paſs, no, it ſhannot, for do what thou wilt, I will not fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Then thou art a Coward ſtill, as rank a one as ever, and I loſe time to talk to thee.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Ay, think ſo, do; I a Coward, 'tis likely, dear heart.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Mr. Raſh, I hope to ſee you and Mr. Muchland Friends ſoon.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I ſhall take little thought about it, ſo let's part; Good Morrow, Mr. Ruffle.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I, good Morrow; Huff me — Good Morrow, Mr. Merry, la, la, la, huff me.

div.stage: Enter Roſe in Man's Cloaths, Honour in a Night-Gown.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Ne're tell me on't, I'm confident ſome unlucky thing will happen, for I ne're perceiv'd my Brother more angry in my Life; I wiſh we had not gone.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I am rather glad we were there; for, knowing of the Quarrel, we can take care to prevent the effects of it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: But we were the occaſions of it, you know.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I think not, for Mr. Raſh was in ſuch'a Quarrelſom humour, and that vapouring Gentleman did ſo puſh it on, that I am confident had not we been there the ſame thing would have hapned.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: within. Siſter, I would ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Immediately. 'Tis my Brother, what ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I'le ſtept into the Cloſet, and hearken, and then go down the back-ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Siſter, ſince I left you, I have had more cauſe to conſider the conſequence of your marrying Mr. Merry then ever I had before, therefore I deſire to know what thoughts you have of him.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Truly, Brother, I cannot pretend an averſion to a Gentleman you commanded me to favour as your Friend, and one you deſign'd I ſhould marry, though further I am no wayes engag'd.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I am glad to ſee your indifferency, for by this morning's work I find you can no wayes hope for that happineſs I once thought you might expect in being his; the Company he keeps is bad, and the conſequences will attend it muſt be worſe, therefore admit of no further addreſſes from him, which the better to prevent, you ſhall towards York-ſhire to morrow.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: To morrow, Sir?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: If ſo, 'tis time for me to beſtir my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I, Siſter, 'twill ſave you ſome bluſhes for ſo abrupt a breaking with him, and I have hopes to live to give you full ſatisfaction for this change, and to beſtow you on one may more deſerve you.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: The manner of your Diſcourſe doth much ſurprize me, and ſeems very myſterious; I hope there is no cauſe thoſe hopes you ſpeak of ſhould prove doubtful ones.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Siſter, I cannot tell, but I deſire, let things go how they will, that you'd prepare your ſelf for all may happen.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, a Gentleman without deſires to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Admit him in.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Sir, your Noble proceedings in ſo Generouſly defending ſtrangers hath bound me for ever to your Service.
