And fearing leſt your Generoſity hath too far engag'd you in our behalfs, I am come to offer you the aſſiſtance of my Sword, thinking I ſhould but ill become the wearing it, if any other ſhould be drawn, and not it in my own Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p:
Sir, you are truly Noble, and I have juſt occaſion to give
thanks to that unlucky Accident, ſince it produced me the Acquaintance of ſo worthy a Perſon.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Sir, your own demeanour is enough to inſpire worth into a Perſon that Naturally wants it, and if I have any, I ſhall impute it to the Example I received this day from you; but to avoyd Complements, of which I am a bad returner, I beg you would employ me.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir, if I do, it ſhall be in an Office in which there ſhall on your part, be no hazzard: Siſter, I deſire you would entertain this Gentleman, whilſt I ſtep into your Cloſet to write a Letter.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Madam, you can no wayes believe the great Obligations I have received this day from your Noble Brother.
But, Madam, not to loſe time, I will ſo mix my ſelf amongſt them, it ſhall be impoſſible, but I'le prevent all miſchief.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I, but the Countrey, and to leave Mr. Merry, Roſe, I am grown deſperate with the thoughts of it.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Prepare your ſelf to go abroad, and leave the reſt to me.
Madam, I dare aſſure your Lady-ſhip 'tis no ſuch matter; and upon my Honour, there is no man in the World ſhall be more careful of Mr. Muchland's ſafety, then my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: You ſeem a Gentleman to be rely'd on.
But, Roſe, if Mr. Merry ſhould be concern'd in the Quarrel after our leaving them, what then?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I'le warrant you, Madam, as I'le contrive the matter, he ſhall be better Friends with Mr. Merry, then ever.
For truly, Madam, I obſerv'd nothing but a little heat about mine, and my Friends Intrution, that was all; and —

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir, I deſire you to deliver this Paper for me where 'tis directed; I beg your pardon for it's being Seal'd, ſince it is rather to rectifie ſome miſtakes between that Gentleman and I, then to purſue them further, though, I confeſs, if he continues his reſentments, I had rather you were witneſs of them then any other Perſon wholly a ſtranger to their firſt beginnings.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Sir, I am proud that you are pleas'd to employ me any way: Your Lady-ſhips Servant.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: But dear Brother, let me beg you, if any thing hath happened between Mr. Merry and you, that cauſes this ſuddain avertion, let me know it, that I may with Juſtice root out of my mind that little eſteem your Friendſhip to him, and his merit hath planted there.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: There is nothing, upon my word, Siſter, but my conſideration of this happineſs hath begot the change I have expreſt.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, here is a Letter, a Porter brought, he ſaith, from the Roſe Tavern.

body.head: Muchland Reades.
body.p: THE Injuries I received from you are unſupportable, nor can a man of Honour, as I profeſs, and ſhall ever teſtifie my ſelf to be, put them up; therefore, I deſire you would meet me ſingly with your Sword in your hand, at the lower ſide of Hide-Park, at ſix this morning, where I doubt not to make you know what it is to Injure the Valiant, and place abuſes upon the Worthy, in the firſt Rank of which I ſhall alwayes be ambitious, to have the Name ſubſcribed of

sp.p: 'Tis dam'd unlucky this, I wiſh I had not ſent my Letter to be Challenged to the ſame place whither I deſir'd Mr. Sharp to come; but ſtay, ſix of the Clock, this is an hour ſooner then I appointed, that's well; for if I be kill'd by this firſt, I ſhall dye the more contentedly, in not having fought my Miſtreſſes Brother, and if I ſurvive, I ſhall be in a condition to make good my word to him. Siſter, prepare for your Journey, and if you have any kindneſs for your ſelf, think not on Mr. Merry.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Not think of him, that's impoſſible; ſhould my Father's Soul riſe from the Grave, and bid me to forget him, I could not do it. No, Brother, his worth hath placed him here too faſt to be by ſmall diſlikes of yours remov'd.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you have had your deſign upon me, what wou'd you more? We all know one another too. I believe that is not to place approbrious Names upon our own Qualities. I take you two to be men that will live, if Dice and Cards will do it; and I am confident you take me to be one that have no mind to leave a thouſand pounds a Year before. I muſt needs, and therefore am ſomething backwards in fighting matters.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: To ſpeak the truth, Mr. Ruffle, I believe you.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Now I dare ſwear, if you would confeſs, there's neither of you love fighting any more then I do.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: I'le aſſure you, Sir, my Reputation was never queſtion'd.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: That I believe, for like the ſubtle Squirrel, you fore-ſee where the Wind will be, and change your Neſt accordingly; but I have a plaguy damn'd humour of deſiring to be thought Valiant, which makes me provoke the beatings, I elſe might go without.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Then you deſerve them, Mr. Ruffle; but I am ſo wiſe, never to regard a beating I get by.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, to continue the good correſpondence our mutual knowing one another hath begun, I have a buſineſs to employ you in, which you effecting dextrouſly, will deſerve I ſhould make the ſum you have got from me already, a compleat hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Name it, Mr. Ruffle.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: And doubt us not.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I have ſent a Challenge to Mr. Muchland, who, I fear, will meet me: Now, if you two will watch him into the Field.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: And kill him for you, you'l give us twenty pounds.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: A very modeſt requeſt to begin Friendſhip with.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Troth, Sir, I have no mind to ſing doleful Ditties through a ſlip knot, not I.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Nor have I any ambition to attain the Title of a proper Gentleman, as I Ride in Triumph on a two wheel'd Chariot.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: No, Sir, as long as the Town is full of Gallants like you, that dare venture their thouſands againſt our nothings, we ſhall not be ſo diſtreſt, as to turn Bravoes.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you run on apace, but 'tis all upon a falſe ſcent; why, I ne're deſir'd the Death of any Man in my Life, and wonder at thoſe they call Men of true Honour, that make no more of killing a Man for refuſing a Health, then I do to eat my Break-faſt: Yet, ſince the Town praiſes theſe hare-brains as Men of worth, I have a huge ambition to be thought one of e'm, ſo I could but obtain it without the danger of my ſelf or Antagoniſt.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Nay, if your deſign be bounded within the compaſs of human ſafety, I'm for you.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: And ten pounds ſhall ne're be ſlighted by me, coming with the hazzard onely of a walk into the Fields.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Then Gentlemen, as I ſaid, dog him thither, and when we are both drawn, appear as taking his part againſt me, place it upon him, as if he had hir'd you; thus our Quarrel will end, and you ſhall have your money.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: If this be all, come away, we're agreed, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: But carry it diſcreetly.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Ne're, ne're fear us; alone, alone, alone, come.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: SIſter, I proteſt his behaviour was unſupportable, he took upon him, as if he had had a right to domineer o're the whole Company.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange, I never obſerv'd his tempet much to incline to Pride.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Not before you, but theſe Country Gentlemen are ſo us'd to controul by the vertue of being Juſtices, that what with their poſitiveneſs on one ſide, and their want of Breeding on the other, a Man had as good keep Company with a Conſtable in midſt of his Bill-men, as with one of them.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Sir, I am come to wait on you, a thing I ſhould not have omitted on my own account, though I now am here but as a Meſſenger.
sp.stage: Delivers him a Letter, which he reads.
sp.p: Madam, I beg your Ladyſhip's pardon for my interruption. Take that.
sp.stage: Roſe gives her a Note privately.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: What ſhould this be? But I perceive it requires ſecreſie.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Sir, I'le aſſure you for ſome reaſons, I had rather you had been the ſender then the bringer of this Letter, but however I ſhall perform it's Contents at the hour appointed.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Sir, I hope I am concern'd more then barely as a Letter Carrier, and ſince I know the moſt material buſineſs of it, I deſire you would ſatisfie my further Curioſity, I yet believing it is intended I ſhould make one at the meeting.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Not at all, I'le aſſure you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange, but I ſhall inquire the cauſe of it elſewhere. Your Ladyſhips moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: What Paper's this? (Reads) For Mrs. Elizabeth Raſh.

body.head: Opens it, and finds.
body.p: MAdam, the Letter I deliver'd your Brother contains a Challenge to meet a Gentleman in Hide Park this Morning at eight of the Clock, I confeſs I muſt needs appear Treacherous, as well for opening the Letter, as for betraying the buſineſs, but when you ſhall know the true motives that made me do both, I am confident you will not onely abſolve me, but allow a place in your eſteem for one who doth all he can to preſerve to you two friends; the loſs of either of which would be a perpetual trouble to you, and real grief to your unknown

sp.p:
This requires care and Expedition to prevent, for the other Friend
he means can be none but Mr. Muchland, I'le make a Viſit to his Siſter, and enquire out the matter.

div.stage: Enter Merry at one Door, and Roſe at the other.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Sir, you are well met; I was going to your Lodging to look for you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Troth, Sir, I am ſorry I am prevented the happineſs of meeting you there, we would have crackt a Bottle e're we had parted.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: It troubles me a little that I muſt tell you my buſineſs would ſcarce have provoked Drinking.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But, Sir, let your buſineſs have been what it would, we would have drunk upon it: For if't had been good, 'twould have deſerv'd a Bottle; and if bad, needed one; and I tell you, Sir, I never ſaw any thing yet in my Life could put me paſt conſideration of a Bottle.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Sir, the pleaſantneſs of your temper, with your Civilities to me and my Friend, makes me ſorry to tell you I am a Meſſenger from a Gentleman, to invite you with your Friend into the 〈◊〉 at Nine this Morning, to meet him that ſent me, and my ſelf; I need not name on what ſcore.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis to Fence for a Break-faſt of Honour, I gueſs the buſineſs well; let him be whom he will, he ſhall not fail of my Company, though I confeſs it ſeems very odd to be invited to a Banquet of Man's fleſh, without knowing a cauſe for the Treat. Pray Sir, the Name of this obliging Friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Muchland, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: How! Marry now I find a kind of a Qualm coming over my ſtomack, which makes me wiſh I could be excus'd on any terms, leſs then loſs of Reputation; yet faith I can't believe but you miſtake your Man, for I was juſt going to his Lodging to take up a Quarrel I fear'd might proceed too far between him and another.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: No, Sir, if your Name be Merry, you are the Man. He imputes the miſ-underſtanding between his Miſtreſſes Brother and him, to the Ill Company you drew him into, and therefore is reſolv'd his Siſter ſhall into the Countrey from you to Morrow; and and he will have ſatisfaction for the injuries he receiv'd in the Tavern from none but your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A Compendious cauſe for a Quarrel, and much as ſignificant as moſt Duels now a days are fought upon: He receives the abuſes from others, and requires ſatisfaction from me, S'death, he might as well have plac'd it on the Vintner for keeping the Houſe, the Link-Boys for lighting him to it; or indeed on his Horſe that brought him his laſt Journey to Town, this Capriciouſneſs of his Temper with his deſign to take from me my Miſtreſs makes me wiſh he was here to begin preſently. Where's the place he deſigns for this dilicate Trial of Skill?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: In Hide-Park, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I ſhall bring a Friend that hath as much cauſe of malice to you as this Man of Punctillioes hath to me, and therefore if you have no more wit, you may fight too.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Sir, I am not afraid to ſay I ſhall ſcarce be idle when I ſee you once engag'd.

div.stage: Enter Townlove and the Lady Turnup in Morning-Gowns.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: My dear Townlove, thou art the goodeſt Rogue for not Drinking, I could e'en bite thee to pieces for it. But faith I'le tell Mr. Merry on it ſoundly when I ſee him for keeping thee up all Night; come, prethee, ſhall we to Bed?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I preſently; but firſt you ſhall ſing me the new Scotch Song.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: No, prethee don't; I am ſo hoarſe with ſitting up for thee, that I ſhall never make any Muſick of it now, and I do ſo long to be in Bed, dear Townlove come, let's go.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I muſt have my Song firſt, time enough for Bed, we'l not Riſe till Dinner time, and that ſhan't be ready till three, that we may have time to go to the Play.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: And will you ſtay with me after the Play, and engage with no Body?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Come, my Song, and I won't.

lg.l: WIllie was ſo blithe a Lad,
Nene like was in the Town;
At Wake and Waſſel Willie had
For Dancing chief Renown.
He pick'd the Bar, and hurl'd a ſtean,
Nea Man wou'd him out-gang;
And if he ſtrave with any ean,
He gard them lig alang.
But Willie needs would Wedded be,
He lik'd ſo weele a Laſs
That bonny was, and full of glee,
And mickle all did paſs.
Yet Willie was no ſooner Wed,
But he full ſear did pine;
He croſs'd his Arms, hang'd down his Head,
And ſtill had watry Eyne.
Ah, wea is me, would Willie ſay,
That I am thus forlorn;
I now can neither Dance nor Play,
Nor ought but wind a Horn.
The Lads and Laſſes all do laugh,
And ſcorn me as I gang;
They do me all a Cuckold knowgh,
And gibe me with this Sang.
Willie ſoon muſt gang to work,
Or Noone ſcodes him ſear;
Maſs Johnne e're he wends to Kirk
Mun con a point we her.
Then Jocky, Sawny, Hugh, and Kit,
Ralph, Wat, and many mere,
Gang when they pleaſe, and take a bit,
Whilſt Willie keeps the Whore.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam, here's Mr. Ruffle will not be ſatisfy'd without he can ſpeak with you; I told him you were aſleep, he ſaid, I muſt wake you, for it may be 'tis the laſt time he ſhall trouble you.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: What doth the Coxcomb mean, to trouble me thus early? Tell him I value my Honour more, then to admit of a Man's Viſit at this time of Day; and ſay, I wonder at his Inſolence: Tell him any thing, rather then let him come up to diſturb my dear Townlove and I now.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I'le hang'd if the Fool hath not run himſelf into ſome Quarrel laſt Night, and now comes to boaſt of his Valour; Will Merry was talking ſomething of it to me, but I ſcarce regarded what I did not believe.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: What a pox is his Valour to me?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: But his thouſand pounds a year is; don't ſlight that.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I, Townlove, you are weary of me, or elſe you would ne're put me upon Marrying that Fool.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Don't you prove your ſelf a worſe, in refuſing ſuch a Fortune; you know my Eſtate is intail'd upon my Younger Brother, then ſhould I dye, what would you do for a maintenance? Beſides, can't I Viſit you then as I do now?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: But will you, dear Townlove?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam, he will not be ſatisfied without ſeeing you; he ſaith, he had rather be ſo unhappy to dye in your diſpleaſure, then without taking his leave; I think he's mad, for he talks of nothing but Honour, Death, Victory, and the like.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Go, bring him up; Townlove, ſtep into the Cloſet, we'l ſee what his mighty concerns are.

div.stage: Enter Ruffle and Maid; when he comes in, walks up and down, ſtamps, ſtarts, and buſtles.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Mr. Rufflle, I'le aſſure you your proceedings, in forcing your ſelf thus into my Chamber, hath given me high diſſatisfaction; you uſe me like one of the common things of the Town, that admit of Viſits in their Beds; but I'le aſſure you I am none of thoſe: My Honour is dearer to me then my Life, and I'le not hazzard the loſs of my Reputation for the ſatisfaction of any Perſon Living.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: It can't be helpt, Madam, the Caſe is alter'd — I am not the Man you think me — no — The World's chang'd — Tempore Mutantur —

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: The World's chang'd indeed; you have not dar'd to uſe me in this ſlight manner formerly, therefore, good Sir, your bus'neſs quickly, that you may be gone, and never ſee my face more.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: There's it, you'l prove a true Propheteſs I fear; but hang't, 'tis no matter, a Man muſt dye, and as good at firſt as at laſt. Honour; I, there's it, to dye, and lye in the Bed of Honour; who would deſire more?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Good Sir, be careful of my Honour, and if your bus'neſs be only to diſturb me, I command your ſpeedy abſence.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Command your Maids abſence, I ſhall tell you all.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: My Maid! Heav'ns forbid! A Man in the Room, and my Maid go out, not for the World! I believe you have ſome deſign upon me, and have ſet your Companions to watch their opportunity to enter when no body's here but us, ſo to force me to Marry you for ſafety of my Reputation; but I'le aſſure you I ſhall be more cautious.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
Madam, your fears are vain — I adore you — And I dare tell you, I merit you now — ſince I am Valiant. You ſaid, you found my want of Valour the greateſt barr to my happineſs.
Alas, alas, Madam, Cowardize was A humour I only put on for a time; but you ſhall hear ſuddenly ſuch things — la, la, la, — will you let your Maid with-draw? Upon my Honour, and by my budding Glory, I have no deſign, but to let you know I merit you — I merit you, that's a bold word, I gad, but I dare ſay it, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Peg, go down, but be ſure to be within hearing, ſhould I call.
Sir, you ſee what hazzards I run to give you ſatisfaction; I'm afraid you'l Interpret this to too much inclination in me, and I wou'd not that for the World.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Madam, you need not fear cenſure for your favouring me, I tell you I deſerve it, for I am Valiant. You know Townlove, don't you?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, what then?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: A very brave Fellow that — And Will Merry too; I have ſeen e'm both Viſit you — And brave Fellows both; by Heav'ns, Madam, they are, as any walks the ſtreets.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I ne're heard otherways: But what then?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: What then? I ſay, damme, blood, ſhould any Bully Rock of e'm all but ſay, or think Townlove or Merry are not as brave Men as Live, I would ſend the lye down their Throats with my double fiſts, that I wou'd; Townlove or Merry not brave! I laugh at that, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: But good Sir, to the bus'neſs.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Why, that's to the bus'neſs, Madam, I tell you they are Gallant, Brave Fellows, and they know one ſhall be nameleſs, that's my ſelf, as brave as either of them, ask e'm when you ſee e'm, how I ſwing'd a couple of Bullys laſt Night; la, la, la. Ask e'm, I ſay, they'l tell you how I duſted e'm about when they were both drawn upon me at once; I feag'd e'm i'faith, they both ſaw it; two on e'm at a time, Madam, won their Money, made meer bubles of e'm, and when I had done, kickt e'm, and turn'd e'm down ſtairs; la, la, la, at the Roſe Tavern: How like you that, Madam?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I am glad you got no hurt, for I Love a Valiant Man and ſhould be ſorry he ſhould get hurt by his Courage. But, Sir, if this be all the bus'neſs, you might have ſtaid telling it till after Dinner.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: All, Madam, 'tis not half; this is only what Townlove and Merry ſaw: All, all, ſay you? Alas, alas, I am to Fight a Duel this Morning in Hide-Park, at ſix of the Clock, with a Man as Valiant as twenty ſuch as they, that's it: I tell you, Madam, this is truth, and therefore, not knowing how Fate will diſpoſe of this Body, I come to aſſure you my Soul is yours, go where it will.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I find I'm over-come by your worth, it muſt not be, do not Fight; you ſay your Soul is mine, then do not take it from me, I will not let you Fight.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Alas, Madam, it can't be helpt — My Honour, my Honour, think o'th' that; la, la, la, I tell you my Honour is dearer to me than my Life.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Or mine either I ſee; O cruel Man, was it with deſign to kill me you came this Morning? Alas, 'tis five a Clock already, and ſix, you ſay's, the hour. Oh, do not go, ſtay here with me, I'le ſay I lockt you up.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis all in vain, your tears are all in vain; my Honour calls me forth, if I be ſlain, as chance of War is doubtful, think ſometimes of poor Ruffle.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Ah, do not think of dying yet, do not go.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Honour, Madam, Honour; think of that: Farewel.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: What the Devil doth the Rogue mean? Not one word of all his beating of two Men in our Company is true; he lay vapouring of his having kickt a Man, to Will Merry, and he believ'd it, but could not perſwade me to be of his Faith, though I believe there may be ſomething in the latter part of the Story.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Let him be hang'd, he is not worth concerning our ſelves about him, prethee Dear, let's to Bed.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Nay, I am confident he'l ſecure himſelf from any danger but dry beating, or kicking, and therefore he ſhall be no part of my care.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Merry muſt ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Bid him come up; what's his bus'neſs, I wonder?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Good Morrow, Madam. What, han't you been in Bed yet, Tow nlove? I ſee you mighty mannagers of Miſſes, that ſeem ſo induſtrious and eager to be at e'm are as long a getting into the Saddle when you have the Bridle in your hand, as Men leſs profeſt in the vaulting Trade.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Troth, Mr. Merry, I could chide you heartily for keeping Mr. Townlove out all Night, when he had promiſed me he would come.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Faith, you'l have greater Reaſon to chide, when I muſt take him from you preſently: Come, prethee Townlove, dreſs, I have buſineſs with you, your Ear —

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I wiſh, Mr. Merry, you were Marryed once, then I hope you will be tam'd, and let Mr. Townlove ſleep in his Bed quietly.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for it, I'le ſlip on my Coat; (help me, Peg,) and go with you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I don't believe you wiſh his buſineſs ſhould be to ſleep quietly in Bed.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Troth, Sir, one good turn is, you ſcarce know what Women wiſh.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: But, Will Merry, here hath been Ruffle, and told ſuch damn'd lyes to Turnup of his Valour, that you ne're heard the like; and quotes you and I for Vouchers.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Dam him, for an unreclaimable Coward, he did nothing but huff when you were gone, becauſe Ned Raſh ſeem'd to take his part; and when I believing him Valiant, would have took him to task, he prov'd the ſame ſneaking thing he always was.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: He tells me he is to fight this Morning at ſix.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Faith, may be he might miſtake a Man, and give a Challenge, but I'le ſecure him from fighting.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: There's ſomething comes in my Head; where are your Fiddles, Merry?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: At the Roſe I left e'm, and bid e'm ſtay for me.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Turnup, we'l ſend e'm to you, and give e'm ſuch Inſtructions, that 'tis ten to one they ſhall play up your Wedding Dinner to Day.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Faith, dear Townlove, I had rather Live as I do.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Gad, Girle, I like thee for this; refuſe a thouſand pounds a year for Love of a Raſcal, that will ne're Marry thee.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I Love Mr. Townlove too well, to deſire to Marry him, if he was ſuch a Fool to have me; now all our pleaſures come freely, but when they once are our Duties, 'twou'd go ſo againſt the hair; no, I'le ne're marry a Man I Love.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: This is the prettieſt ſort of new Philoſophy in Love; right Deſcartes, it depends all upon motion. Why, what wou'd Lucrece, Cornelie, and the reſt of the Ancient Husband Lovers ſay; did they ſee theſe dayes?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Why, Merry, no doubt but they would be converted to Love for delight, and Marry for conveniency, as Turnup here ſhall do, therefore I charge you mannage your buſineſs ſo, as I may ſalute you the next time I ſee you, by the Name of Ruffle.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Well, Townlove, I did not think you would have left me ſo ſoon; but I will do what you bid me, to ſhew you that I can Love better than you in diſpoſing of my ſelf, that you may get a new Miſtreſs, for I know there's your aim.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A gallant Trade, let me be hang'd elſe.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Come, let's away.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Was e're ſo croſs a miſchief known? I'm confident Mr. Merry meant nothing but mirth.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: 'Twas that untimely mirth, to which we owe all this diſtraction; Curſe on his Revels, and may he be condemn'd ne're to take Reſt that hath by this Nights waking, rob'd me, I fear, of quiet during Life.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Madam, me-thinks you are too paſſionate, and ſomething like your Brother, to whom in Juſtice you ſhould impute all miſchief that ſhall happen; for I'm ſure it was his onely fault theſe Quarrels ris.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p:
'Tis you are paſſionate, and blinded too by your concerns
for Merry; he, I ſay, who, could he keep his Bed, and leave his Fooling, wou'd not be Author of ſo many broyls his drunkenneſs muſt daily now occaſion.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: This Language, Madam, better would beſeem your Land-Lady, when in a high concern for tother farthing Candle, ſhe wou'd rate your Foot-man for the evil hours he keeps. To tax a Gentleman with Drunkenneſs, is proper for no mouth but ſuch a one as makes the loudeſt noiſe in crying Oyſters.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Oh, that we both were Men but for an hour, and all the Quarrel ours, though bound to end it with our Lives.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I cannot wiſh to leave the World ſo ſoon, ſince there is ſomething in it I muſt like, in ſpight of all detraction. But truly, Madam, I could hazzard much againſt the Siſter of that Man I know attempts my Brother's Life.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Your Brother (Oh, that I live to ſay it) caus'd that Quarrel, as you do this; t'was he that ſent the Challenge.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: 'Tis likely then, he had occaſion for it.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Oh, yes, occaſion; he could not ſure want that, ſince I'm his Miſtreſs; one he fain would break with, and wants a fit pretence; but ſure he need not have gone ſo far about, for I believe he ne're had mighty cauſe to think I doted.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: No, Madam, to deal freely, I've obſerv'd your Pride ſtill ſtrugled with your Inclination; yet had he not been blinded by his Paſſion, he might have ſeen through all your ſcorns a likeing.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Ill-temper'd Maid, thus to abuſe my Patience: Oh, for two Swords, that Women, though we are, we yet might try whether our feeble Arms were wholly wanting to our Active ſpleens.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Your wiſh ſo hearty ſeems, it wou'd be pity you ſhould not have it granted; and I find your braves have ſo diſperſt all fear in me, that I as much do long to try this fighting, as you can ſeem to do; ſtay but a little, I ſoon can find two Swords.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Do't then, and if I don't ſoon make you feel th' effects of Anger, though by weakneſs backt, then let me be deſpis'd by all that Love me.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Here are the Swords.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Come, give me one, I long to ſee it drawn.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Nay, ſtay, you ſhannot have the longeſt; there, take that.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Let me feel the point — 'tis ſharp, I warrant you I'le make it enter.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Enter where? I hope you do not mean to kill me.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Come, come, lets fight; what, Weapons in our hands, and ſpend our time in talking.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Hey day, what's here, two Women-Duellers? Some fighting Planet Reigns to day ſure: Ladies, 'tis very pretty, you that ſhould be Active in making Peace between your Brothers, are practiſing the Art to be their Seconds. Me-thinks a naked Weapon, with ſo ſharp a point, is not very proper for your Ladyſhips hand, pray let me take it from you.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Sir, 'tis not ſo eaſie to take a Sword from me, as you imagine.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: But I'le aſſure you, Lady, I muſt prevent all fighting, 'tis my buſineſs; therefore relate the Quarrel, that I may make you Friends.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: No Relations, Sir; our Quarrels Love and Honour, that's enough.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Enough, ſay you? I, to ſet the whole World together by the Ears, or to make e'm Friends again either: Love and Honour are the two great Wheels, on which all buſineſs moves. The Tradeſman Cheats you upon his Honour, and like a Lord ſwears by that, but that he particularly loves you, you ſhould not have it ſo. No Tragedy, Comedy, Farſe, Demi-Farſe, or Song now adayes, but is full of Love and Honour: Your Coffe-drinking-Crop-ear'd-Little Banded-Secretary, that pretends not to know more of Honour than it's Name, will out of abundance of Love be ſtill ſighing and groaning for the Honour of the Nation. Nay, the Lady, that for Impudence ſake hides her Face behind a Vizzard, will proteſt in taking the mollifying Guinney, that it is not that, but the confidence ſhe hath that the Gallant will be careful of her Honour, and becauſe ſhe loves him, that makes her beſtow ſo conſiderable a Pox upon him: And therefore, Ladies, if Love and Honour be the motive of your unuſual Valour, 'tis ten to one you may do wonders with your Weapons without going to Fencing Schools.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p:
Come, prethee, Roſe, leave Fooling, and tell us in what
poſture our unlucky affairs are, for I am more for that, then for fighting.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Roſe, ſaid you?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Yes, the very ſame, at your Ladyſhips Service, though very unable, you'l ſay, to do much.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Prethee, how comes this Diſguiſe?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: To play the part of a right Town Gallant, raiſe Quarrels, and then prevent them by Diſcovery, this is the way moſt Men find to Honour now adayes; the Quarrel is begun with Son of a Whore, you Lye, or a box on the Ear, ſlight matters, not able to provoke heat of Blood enough to fight preſently, but the formal Challenge muſt follow, the Seconds muſt confer, and the Swords be meaſur'd in order to a meeting the next Morning in the Field; which none of the four but thinks himſelf bound by the Religious Rules of ſelf-preſervation to prevent, and therefore each whiſpers the matter to one of his beſt Friends at leaſt, and the Devil's in't, if none of them will find one that loves him ſo well to riſe a little earlier, to fetch a Guard to prevent all. And you muſt think they are ſoon made Friends, their meek Dove-like Honour being ſafe.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I never diſcover'd talking to be the Crime of our Sex before: I thought it had been a ſcandal placed upon us, but I ſee now 'tis true; for I never heard ſo many words to ſo little purpoſe from one that wore a pair of Breeches in my Life. Prethee, Roſe, leave this talkative humour, and tell me how matters ſtand.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Why, Ladies both, they ſtand as you would have e'm ſtand; therefore do but prepare your ſelves to go whither I will conduct you, if you are not throughly pleas'd with their ſtanding before to Morrow Morning, let Roſe be condemn'd never to have to do with any thing within a pair of Breeches again.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Well, Roſe, I will believe 'tis thy Morning's draught makes thy Tongue run thus wildly, pray heav'n it be'nt before thy wit.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: No fears, Madam, though I muſt tell you Mr. Merry has receiv'd a Challenge this morning as well as the reſt.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: He Challeng'd! By whom, dear Roſe, tell me.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: No, I ſhould talk too much, ſhould I tell you; I will have a care of running into that error again.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Cruel Wench, to put me in a fright thus.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I am glad to ſee you puniſht with your fears for Merry's ſafety, me-thinks through all your ſcorns, was he but hear, he might diſcern a liking.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I did deſerve your Anger, Madam, for urging that of which my ſelf was guilty; but pardon me, I hope this falling out will but confirm our Friendſhips.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I doubt it not, if Roſe makes good her word.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Why brave, i'faith, you're Bully Rocks exactly, and know to the ſplinter of a hair when to draw, and when to put up with Honour; Maſquerading muſt needs go on, when Women practice the ſubſtantial'ſt part of Man, that's drawing Naked Weapons. But come, a Coach waits at the Door to convey you where you may have opportunity to try your Courages a ſafer way, though I will not affirm without Blood-ſhed.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Thou art run ſtark mad, Roſe.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: And we, I fear, are as mad, to believe any thing ſhe ſaith.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: But if you believe not me, go where you may truſt your ſenſes, I hope hearing and ſeeing, or at leaſt, the moſt excellent ſenſe feeling will be truſted by you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
He is not come, I ſee; faith two to one he dares not: For I have ſeen many man with as fighting a Face, and as apt to throw a Tobacco-pipe too, that hath been as backwards when matters have come to the puſh as men of eaſier fleam; I, gad, I hope this will prove a lucky Adventure, but then I might have ſav'd the money I am to give Breef and Fullam for prevention; a plague on't, that we heartleſs men can't know one another by ſympathy, 'tis true, by experience on my ſelf, I can give a pretty near gueſs, and therefore I never hear a man that's apt to ſpeak ill of others behind their backs under the Seal of ſecrecy, or that enquires for mens Names that are Cowards, to report them ſo in all Companies they come in, or that
is alwayes drawing a Sword, to talk of fancying a paſs, or that never ſees a pale, young, or ſickly Face, but he makes it red with bluſhing at the abuſes he puts upon it, or indeed one that ſeems alwayes ſo big with Valour, that by Hectoring, huffing, talking of Duels, and breaking Drawers pates, doth, as it were, cry out to be deliver'd of this Tympany of Courage — S'blood, what's that comes yonder? By heav'ns my man — And no ſight of my hirelings — No where to get out of ſight till they appear — No, 'tis impoſſible but he ſees me: What the Devil ſhall I do — I think I had beſt fall to Queries about the Quarrel — a way many a Young Gallant hath prevented the pinking his Doublet by — Ne're ſtir, me-thinks the danger makes me think I dare fight; I, gad, I'le do't; hang it, it is but dying, and that I muſt do at laſt in ſpight of my teeth.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir, I ſee your Anger hath made you get the ſtart, both of the hour and me; 'tis hardly ſix.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Your provocation made it ſeem ſo to me an hour agone — and I do wonder —

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Let's not loſe more time in talking then, the diſpatch I intend with my Sword ſhall make amends for the time you loſt by ſtaying.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sir, I'm ignorant who is your Taylor, and therefore might enquire with what he lynes your Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: You have reaſon, Sir, I think our Shirts an't proof.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I think we had beſt to ſtrip then, not that I doubt your Honour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: That's as you pleaſe, Sir, it muſt relye on proof.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sure I dare fight — the Spirit comes upon me: And this Gentleman ſeems ſo careleſs of it, that I believe there's not that danger in ſighting I once thought — but wou'd the Rogues would come thought.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Almoſt, Sir, a curſed Band-ſtring hampers my Button ſo, I can't undo't.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Shall I help you?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: No, Sir — Gad, they're coming —
I've done it, come, Sir; but what two men are yonder?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Some to prevent us, I dare lay my Life, they run ſo faſt; but let's make haſte, we may out-do their diligence.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I hope we may.
sp.stage: They fight, Ruffle parries and traverſes. Enter Fullam and Breef.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Hold, Mr. Ruffle, you are a dead Man elſe.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Sir, we beg your pardon, we came no ſooner to your Reſcue.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: But we are glad our Swords were not wholly prevented from ſerving you.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Gentlemen, what mean you to excuſe your abſence ſo long, ſince I could wiſh the courteſie had ſtill continued.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: We cannot blame you to be a little Angry, ſince we were not ſo diligent in performing our words as we promis'd.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: What words? What promiſe? Gentlemen, I never ſaw you before in my Life, as I know of.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: What, Sir, not at the Roſe Tavern this morning, when we engag'd our words to do you Service againſt this Gentleman, as we are ready, then let us uſe no time, for yonder's Company.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir, give me leave to tell you, y'are both Villains, that would contrive the murder of my Honour, a thing much dearer to me than my Life; therefore, Sir, as you are a Gentleman, joyn, but and drive theſe Raſcals from our ſight, or from the World, and then we'l fight in quiet.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Your Dialogue is too myſterious, Sir, for me to mix with; therefore ſtand off, if I'm ordain'd to dye now, none ſhall ſay I did not ſell my Life at Honours utmoſt rate, then do your worſt, this Tree ſhall guard my Back, and this my Face.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Come, Sir, fall on, and let's diſpatch him quickly.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I'm here againſt you both: If you be Thieves, come, kill me firſt, then do the like by him, and take our plunder; but I am reſolv'd no fear ſhall let you take my Honour from me.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Sir, what do you mean? You carry things too far.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Come, do your worſt; why ſo long a joyning?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Oh heavens, what Fate is this?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Put up your Swords, and come along with us; muſt we be alwayes plagu'd with your raſh Quarrels?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir, as you're a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: No talking, Sir, to us; our Captain, perhaps, will hear you ſpeak.

div.head: The Fifth Act.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: SInce we are met, I ſee there is a neceſſity of opening our minds one to another before we can part: Faith, ſay, is not your buſineſs fighting?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I'm afraid it will prove ſo e're we go home, though conſidering every thing, I had much rather have walk'd abroad ſo early a Simpling, to gather herbs for a Dyet-drink, and took it when I had done, though it be the Liquor of all others I moſt abhor.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs I am here on the like Errand, and ſhould be loath to be prevented, though how we ſhall ſave our Reputations to our ſeveral Adverſaries when they find us together, I am to ſeek; nor is it reaſon for either to deſire the Field, ſhould be cleared by the other.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I'le make a propoſition; you ſhall declare to each other the men you are to meet, then I will be upon the Scout, and give notice who approaches firſt, on which the other ſhall withdraw.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I like the propoſition well; what ſay you, Merry?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: The Gentleman I am to deal with, is one I would rather compoſe then fight with, and having little or no occaſion for the Quarrel, I hope to give Reaſons may end the buſineſs without noiſe, and therefore would be glad to ſpare Names.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p:
There can be little occaſion for that caution, ſince, I ſuppoſe, we are all too much Gentlemen, to be thought bablers; and
to ſhew I have reſerves, notwithſtanding I know your pretences; Mr. Merry, I dare tell you, 'tis Mr. Muchland I ſtay for.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Mr. Muchland! By what motives do you ſtay for him?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Mov'd by a formal Challenge, ſent in writing, to meet him ſingly here: But who's your Man?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, I have reaſons force me to conceal his Name. But you ſurprize me much, and though I know that words went high between you, I ne're thought they could have mov'd a Challenge: Pray, Sir, who brought it?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Your cautious dealing teaches me the ſame, though, I confeſs, too late.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I've no ſuch Obligations; and ſince I ſee there's ſomething foul in this, I will not ſpare to ſay, 'tis by Mr. Muchland's appointment we are likewiſe here now; and I am ſorry to ſee, that Challenging two Men together to one place, his Courage dare meet neither.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Townlove, don't wrong a Man you never try'd.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: He that ſeeks further tryal let him find it, I'm ſatisfied, if words will fright a Man, he ſhan't want them from him; but prethee tell, what Man did bring thy Challenge?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: One of thoſe Gentlemen we met i'th' ſtreet; he that durſt drink.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: The ſame that came to me; 'tis plain, they do but Jeſt, and ſent us hither only to laugh at us.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: My Temper's not ſo pleaſant to find out Jeſts in formal Challenges.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nor mine ſo ſowr, but I can take for Jeſt all that is meant ſo.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: All that occurs to me on the whole matter, is this, that we may all go back again, and wait his Explanation of the Riddle.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, deliver up your Swords, you'l have no uſe of e'm, it ſeems, to day.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I pray Sir, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: We are ſent to prevent the Duel you are come about.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: It ſeem we came about no Duel, Sir, and you may ſpare your pains.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: You are merry, Sir, but we muſt do our Duty; then give us up your Swords.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Where is it we muſt go?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: The back way to the Mulberry-Garden; they who employ'd us wait our coming thither: But we want another, they ſaid we ſhould find four.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: It was a needleſs caution in e'm, be who they will; for that fourth man you ſpeak of is as good as forty Guards at preventing Duels.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come, go on, we'l be your Peaceful Priſoners, though you permit our Swords.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis enough; march on.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I am ſurpriz'd extreamly, here is a Guard hath brought in four Gentlemen already they took Actively fighting, as they ſay, and Mr. Muchland's one, I ſaw him through the Door.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: This is your diligence, good Mrs. Roſe, you have undone us, for if they've fought, they then will ne're be Friends.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What a Fool was I to truſt ſo weighty a concern to the conduct of a wanton, hare-brain'd Wench.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Ne're ſtir, Roſe, compoſe all matters, as you promis'd, or you ſhall find what 'tis to raiſe my expectation high, and then to fool me.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: 'Tis not your wanton Jeſts ſhall bring you off, I'le ſwear you ſhan't Live with me a day longer, if you fail your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Hey day, will you but give me leave to ſpeak; you're as pettiſh both of you as two Puritan Siſters, condemn'd to dye Maids, the greateſt Curſe accounted by the Saints of our Reformation that can be.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What can you ſay? Flam us off with ſome untoward Jeſt; no, forſooth, that ſhall not ſerve your turn.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I don't intend it ſhall, have but patience, that I may go and mix in Company with theſe ſame Duellers, if I don't ſet all things right again, let me be diſcarded by your Ladyſhip, and bound to fight a Duel with yours.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Let's ſee the effects of your promiſes quickly, or the Duel you ſpeak of may prove a ſharper then you believe.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: If the Guard I have ſent out catch any Quarry, let them keep e'm cloſe in ſome Room till I return.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: It ſhall be done, but let us have no more failings on your part.

div.stage: Enter Muchland, firſt Officer, Fullam, and Breef.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: By a Woman's directions, it ſeems, you ſurpriz'd us, and ſhe's a Friend of Ruffle's.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and they're together; I believe they will Marry, for a Parſon is ſent for.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: You ſeem a Man of Reaſon; your Ear.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: This Ruffle will cheat us of what he promis'd, for he told me juſt now we came too late, and that the danger was paſt, he being forced to fight e're we Reliev'd him.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: He curſt and ſwore when I but ſpoke to him, and told me he would have me toſt in a Blanket if I but mention'd money to him. Nay, he ſwore damn him, if in the humour he was in, he could not have beat us all three. And I believe he is Valiant, for we, you know, found him ſtript and fighting.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: But he parryed and traverſt damnably faſt, and I'm convinc'd by Experience, that all Men who draw Swords are not Valiant; and that the Diſeaſe of Cowardiſe, when once proof againſt the Phyſick of beating, as his oft hath been, is incurable.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: I cannot tell, but if we were once well off with what we got to Night, I would forgive him my Mornings hire.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: I'm of your mind for that, I could admit of an eaſie excuſe to be going.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer.
sp.p: Sir, you have ſatisfied me, and 'tis but reaſon; I'le take care you ſhannot be diſturb'd.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, my Old Acquaintance, and very good
Friends that I never ſaw before, what motives had you to uſe me as you did i'th' Field juſt now?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Uſe you, how did we uſe you? Were not we civil in taking of your part? Damme, what wou'd you be at?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: No huſſing, Raſcals, that will not do with me, I'm none of thoſe — Come, tell me preſently what made
you intereſt your ſelves in my concerns with ſuch a lye to back it, as if I had employ'd you? Come, Sir, ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Very pretty: Breef, didſt ever ſee the like? The Gallant knows us both for men of Honour, he durſt not elſe provoke two of us thus.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Men of Honour i'th' Devils Name: A pair of Curs in couples are not more tame, nor readier for a beating; you huffing Raſcal, anſwer, what made you do't?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: This is unſufferable, I am a Gentleman, and therefore do require ſatisfaction for this abuſe; meet me ſingly with your Sword then to morrow morning at the place where I ſav'd your Life and Honour both to day.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Town tricks right; I'le try you firſt how far a Cudgel will provoke your paſſion.
sp.stage: Exit Muchland, and bolts the Door.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: What ſhall we do, he hath lock'd the Door, or elſe we might have got Ruffle to take our parts.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Gad, let's both draw, and try to keep him off till the Guard hears.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Hang't, that won't do; I ſee he's one of thoſe that count their Honour dearer then their Lives; and Hell, Damnation, the Devil and all are not able to fright them from fighting when they are ſet on't. And though by my manner of Living I ſhould fear Hell as little as any Man, yet I could never perſwade my ſelf to be ready to dye, neither by Sword nor Hanging, one of which uſually follows the fighting of Men that Live in publick fame as I do.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Why then let's reſolve to ſuffer bravely, 'tis but a beating he'l give us, and he'l ſoon give over the Cudgel, if he be a Man of Honour as thou think'ſt he is.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p:
I, but he is a Man of Countrey Honour, and they go a great way farther in beating a Man then your City Man of Honour doth. Alas, I know e'm both, the one is contented to give the
ſingle Battoon of diſgrace, but the tother ne're thinks it enough till he makes your skin o'th' colour of your hair. I am for down-right confeſſing all.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: That's worſe by half, for then we fall under the Revenge of Ruffle, and nothing like being in the power of an inraged Coward.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: He comes, oh, heart, heart, hold breaking.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Come, Gallants, I ſhould be loath to make uſe of theſe edgeleſs Weapons, therefore confeſs, and ſave me and your ſelves the trouble.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: S'death, Sir, I hope you do not intend to be rude to Gentlemen in Cuſtody; you know we are Priſoners, or elſe —

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Or elſe you would run away, therefore I'le begin with you.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir — Damme, this muſt not paſs — Revenge muſt follow — aſſure your ſelf it muſt —

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I do conſider that, and will give you a little thinking time, whilſt I exerciſe your Comerade.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Good Sir, be civil, you know I han't gave you a word to diſpleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Confeſs, Sir, then; confeſs.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Hold, good Sir, and I will.

sp.speaker: Ful
sp.p: Cowardly Raſcal; what, doſt fear a beating?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Pray valiant Sir, ſtand by: Come, Sir, your ſtory.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Sir, we were hir'd by Mr. Ruffle to come into the Field, and ſeem to take your part, to get him Honour.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: What ſay you, Sir? Is this ſtory true?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis a truth, but I'd have ſooner dy'd then told it you. Out, you hen-hearted Coward.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Go, Sirrah, and kick him for calling you Coward.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Gad, I wou'd he durſt.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Do't, or I'le Baſtinado you again.
sp.stage: Breef takes up a ſtick, and goes to beat Fullam, who takes up another, and worſts him.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Gad, I'le teach you to ſtrike me, you Cowardly Rogue.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: So, well done; now we ſhall ſoon be Friends.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Friends, Sir; no, Gad, I'le no Friendſhip with you.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer.
sp.p: This Gentlemans importunity hath forc'd me to introduce him to you.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: He's truly welcome.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Sir, I am much ſurprized to find you here.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: You have reaſon for your wonder, but will not have ſo long, when I ſhall tell you the cauſe of my ſurpriſal, but now I have not time, I muſt deſire you to haſte into the Park to find out Mr. Sharp, and bring him hither, my Honour elſe may ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I ſhall obey you, and return preſently.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Come, my moſt excellent brace of Spanniels, you muſt go and witneſs what you've ſaid.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: I'le witneſs nothing, not I.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer.
sp.p: Come, Sir, no muttering, march.

div.stage: Enter Honour, Betty, and ſecond Officer.

sp.speaker: 2. Officer.
sp.p: The Gentlemen we have taken, call themſelves Raſh, Merry, and Townlove.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: You have done well; keep e'm upon your Lives.

sp.speaker: 2. Officer.
sp.p: Ne're fear it, Madam, they are ſafe enough.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: We're ſure by this 'tis none of them that fought with Mr. Muchland.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: No, that matter's plain, and I begin to gueſs the Man; but here comes Roſe will tell all. Oh, excellent Roſe, thy Guard of new made Red-Coats have done their buſineſs bravely; they've brought in Merry, Raſh, and Townlove.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I, now 'tis excellent Roſe; but by and by you'l call me longtong'd, ſhallow-pate again: I am ſo elevated with the ſucceſs of my buſineſs, that like a new-made Biſhop, I could appear extreamly grave and moody.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Nay, Roſe, no ſtop of thy Induſtry for this favour of Fortune, for ſhould ſhe frown again, thy condition, like a diſgrac'd Favourites, would be more ſubject to oppreſſion, then if never ſhe had ſmil'd upon thee.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I'faith, I believe you, for 'tis not the well-contriv'd project, but the ſucceſsful one is commended; and therefore I'le go on to projection. Step into that Cloſet there.
Officer, bring in your Priſoners.

div.stage: Enter ſecond Officer, with Raſh, Merry, and Townlove.
div.p: Gentlemen, you are welcome to the Mulberry-Garden.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: You'l have our thanks, Sir, as we find our uſage.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: It cannot well be worſe then what I ſuffer'd at our firſt meeting, Sir.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Come, to the buſineſs, Sir; what wou'd you with us?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: By your demand you almoſt make me think I am your Priſoner, but I muſt have other Language from you e're we part.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Sir, you need uſe little ceremony in what you mean to do; your Souldiers, if you command them, took us in the Field, you know as well as we why we were there.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: And there may come a time you may account for it.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: No threatning, Sir, for you are leaſt concern'd, and ſince I am reſolv'd to examine you apart, you ſhall be the firſt I'le talk with. Officer, put that Gentleman into that Room,
sp.stage: Puts Merry in to Honour and Betty.
sp.p: take that along with you, and leave this angry Man for me to talk with.
sp.stage: Exeunt all but Roſe and Townlove.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and what's all this for?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: You told me once to day, you wiſht my Friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I did ſo, when I took you for a Man of Honour, but now I ſee you're none, I ſlight your Friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: In what don't I appear the ſame Man ſtill?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: You carry Challenges baſely intermixt, and yet prevent all ſighting by making us Priſoners, and uſe us too as't 'twere for Crimes of State we were Committed.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: High accuſations, and with much Anger urg'd; but ſuppoſe Roſe ſhould like the propoſition you made her to day, and that I had been the main Inſtrument to bring it about, would you not be pleas'd with me then?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: No, ſaith, ſhould I not; for I believe if ſo, ſhe's but your leavings, and I d be loath to keep her on thoſe terms.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I will not ſay, but I know whether Roſe be a M • n or a Woman: But what then? I dare be ſworn for her • o Man elſe doth; then why ſo coy? I do believe you have kept 〈…〉 Commendations.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: That's no matter, I took e'm from better Friends then; but to the buſineſs, Sir, and then diſmiſs me.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: You're at the buſineſs now; I'm Roſe her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: The Devil thou art; but now I look on thee better, 'tis thee; but what Gallant was he with you, Roſe? I'm afraid you are pre-ingaged.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: It was a Woman too; no mote of that, I'le tell you all anon: Why an't you ſuricus, appoint the place to meet in for our Duel? I know you'l Challenge me.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I, to a Bed, dear Roſe; that, that's the place we'l meet in.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Soft and fair, two words more to that bargain; your preſent buſineſs is to take up Quarrels, for Mr. Merry's is ended I do believe by this; don't ſeem to know me, not nothing of the frolick to my Lady, as you love me; ſhe's here, and Raſhes Siſter with her.

div.stage: Enter Muchland, Ruffle, Breef, and Fullam.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Upon my Honour all they ſay is falſe, and you may think ſo by what they've done: Take beaten Raſcals words, they ſpeak for fear.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I would be glad to think ſo.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: And I'le convince you preſently; lend me your Cudgel.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: What do you mean, Mr. Ruffle? As I'm a Gentleman, do what he could, I never would confeſs.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Then was it you that ſaid it, Villain?

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs my frailty; it was I.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Oh, was it ſo?

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: But he confirm'd it too.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Then he ſhall have it too.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Hold, hold, good Sir, hold.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Did I then hire you to it?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: No, Sir, I ſay, and ſwore it too before.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: What ſay you, Raſcal?

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Truly I cannot tell; I think you did not.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: You ſee what Rogues are here.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I'm ſatisfied, and therefore let e'm go.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: To end this matter now, and ſince theſe Rogues have plac'd a ſcandal on you, wipe it off; come, to your Sword.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sir, I'm new Married, and will not fight to day.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Oh, the multitude of ſeveral ſorts of Cowards there are in the World! Come, without more ado, confeſs your ſelf one.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Confeſs my ſelf a Coward, that's pretty, i'faith; have not you ſeen me meet you in the Field, Fight you, beat theſe Raſcals for traducing me, and yet confeſs my ſelt a Coward, becauſe I don't think it proper to fight on my Wedding-day? A very modeſt propoſition. No, Sir, I'd have you know, this is a day of Joy, I have Marryed a Lady worth thouſands, beſides, for Beauty, Virtue, and good Breeding, I'le defie you to match her between the Tower and Weſtminſter-Hall. She it was, that hearing of our Quarrel, ſent the Guard to ſurprize us; and ſhall I wrong the Love of ſo Excellent a Lady for your humour? Damme, Blood, you make me mad that you do.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I wiſh I could ſee the effects of it, but not to ſpend time in words, the caſe is this; either confeſs you hir'd thoſe Fellows to come into the Field, that you likewiſe told your Wife that now is, of the Quarrel on purpoſe to be ſurpriz'd, and that you are a Coward, and dare not fight. And all this to be openly done before as many as I ſhall appoint to hear it, or prepare your ſelf to dye, for that muſt be your Fate or mine before we part this Room.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Tell me, Sir, do you think you Act now like a Man of Honour — Heav'ns, how Men miſtake themſelves; would you place this upon a Man that you thought durſt fight? Tell me that, would you?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: No, Sir, I ſhould not.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: there's it, and yet you hope to be counted a brave Man for this — Damme, Blood, if I could not find in my heart to break my Reſolution of not Fighting to day, rather then ſuffer you to go away with it thus. But ſince my word was paſt before for not fighting (and 'tis the greateſt part of Honour to keep that) I will humour you in tother: But, Sir, let it be done ſo, that it may not grieve my Wife; and write down the words that I muſt ſay, that there may be no new occaſion for breach of Friendſhip between you and I.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I ſhall do it. Who waits there?
Bring a Pen and Ink to the next Room.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Sir, I have perform'd your Commands; the Gentleman is in another Room.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: He ſhall ſoon ſee the occaſion of my failing him.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sir, your moſt obedient Servant, you are a Friend of Mr. Muchland's here; upon my Life a worthy Man he is: He and I have been merry together this Morning.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: By the Guard that waits, I thought it had been otherways.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: You mean, you thought us fighting; but that hinders no mirth, Men of Honour never fall out about that — though I could tell you, as a Friend of his, I was once deſperately afraid I had kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Why, did you Wound him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: No, but I'le tell you, he ſtood upon his Guard, as't might be thus; and to ſpeak truth, would not budge one foot, I'le ſay that for him; I made a paſs or two, as't might be thus; he parryed, but I reſolv'd to make an end on't quickly, ſeeing ſome People coming, therefore I made a through paſs, and run my Sword to'th' hilts.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: In's ſhirt, it prov'd to be in's ſhirt; but I, Gad, I was upon flying, if the Guard had not come and took us.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: It ſeems there was no cauſe, having done him no hurt.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I knew not that; but I Gad, he's your Friend, preſerve him ſo, for there breaths not a braver fellow, take that from me. But, Sir, upon your Honour ſpeak not a word of this, I know he'l have you Spectator of a frolick we have agreed on; 'tis that I will not have confidence to ſpeak ſome words openly that he ſhall write, but I Gad, let e'm be as bad as they will, I'le ſpeak e'm, let who will be by.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: There are the words, look e'm over, I'le tell you when to ſpeak e'm.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Then if I do it not, take me and hang me.

div.stage: Enter Merry, Townlove, Honour, Betty, and Raſh.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes truly, Sir, the Gentleman that brought you the Challenge gave me notice of it, and had I not Reaſon to take the beſt care I could to prevent it?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: They took care enough themſelves, it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Faith, Raſh, I had once as ill an Opinion of their proceedings as you, but now I am fully ſatisfied in every particular.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I am glad I out-went you both in true conſidering, for you know it would never out of my head, but that Muchland was all worth. Oh, the Excellent Advantages Men have by Wine! it leaves a certain Spirit in ones head, like that of Propheſie.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Like it indeed; Propheſie being a ſort of madneſs, that fills the head, and intoxicates the Underſtanding, making Men ſpeak abundance of things they neither believe themſelves, nor any Body elſe, till ſomething comes to paſs by chance that they ſeem'd to foretell. And then oh, the wonder, as if they that fore-told what could not be prevented, were not altogether as uſeleſs Members to a Common-Wealth, as a ſick Paſſenger at Sea is to a ſinking Ship, when he bellows out between Praying and Swearing; God, we are all loſt.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Prethee leave, I'm for no Morals, or long-winded ſimelies. Here comes the Lad I am for.
One that underſtands his Glaſs, and makes himſelf and his Company merry without detracting from his abſent, or ſatiriſing on his preſent Friend.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Well, our little Projecter, how go matters? I could for thy ſake turn Woodcock in the Play, and alwayes be kiſſing.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: If you ſtop my mouth thus, how ſhall I tell what you would know: But are you all agreed upon the matter?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Onely Ned Raſh hath a little grumbling diſcontent towards you ſtill.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I ſhall ſoon Cure that; come, you muſt go all of you to the Balcony, and there you ſhall ſee what Heroes Mr. Muchland hath been engag'd withal this Morning. And, Mr. Raſh, if your Siſter do not make Mr. Muchland and you, and I too Friends, before we part, I'le be condemn'd to ſing Fortune my Foe in a Nunnery all dayes of my Life.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: In a Nunnery! What have you to do with a Nunnery?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: You ſay right indeed, for if the bargain go on you wot on, I ſhould have little to do with a Nunnery, though I were condemn'd to wear Petticoats; but no more of thoſe miſtakes, but away.

div.stage: Enter Muchland, Ruffle, Fullam, Breef, firſt Officer, and Guard.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Gad, Mr. Muchland, the words are too ſevere, there is no enduring of e'm — let me leave out this Sentence: And like a Cowardly Son of a Whore as I am: Look you, Sir, this is abuſing of my Mother, and ſhe had not the leaſt hand in the Quarrel. What ſay you, Sir, is not this Reaſon?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Gad, Sir, I wou'd ſooner dye then ſay it.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: You'l ſooner be hang'd then dye, like a Cowardly Raſcal as you are.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: You may ſay what you will, but there are them in Town know me for another ſort of Man I dare aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Then the Song, Mr. Muchland, you know that goeth beyond the bargain.
sp.stage: Enter on one ſide all the Company, and Turnup.
sp.p: What, all them, and my own dear Wife too. By Heav'ns I'le dye ten thouſand Deaths before I'le do't. Your Servant, Gentlemen; your Servant, Ladies. A merry Craſh hath hapned between Mr. Muchland and I; we are here Drolling one upon another: Gad, Mr. Muchland, if you had not the ill Nature of all the Juſtices in your whole Countrey, you would never urge me to it, I never will conſent to read the Paper, and ſing the Song too, that's flat.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Well, on condition, you'l all of you ſing, and Act the Song to the Life, I am contented you ſhall only deliver the Paper to Mr. Raſh, and confeſs it to be all a truth.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I'le do't, here's my hand on't; Mr. Raſh is a worthy Gentleman, and knoweth me well enough: Come down, come down, I and theſe Gentlemen are to ſing a mad Song to you.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: He that ſpares, either in kicking or cuffing, ſhall find me upon his back with this.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Damme, if either of you kick, or ſtrike me hard, I'le ſwinge you when we have done.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: I'le warrant you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: I'le do as I ſee cauſe: Breef, have you a care of my Boyl you had beſt, or look to't.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir, I hope this Gentleman hath inform'd you with what reſentments I intended to repair my Reputation, which I look'd upon as too deeply wounded for your ſelf to excuſe my ſilence in it, and likewiſe by what unlucky Accident I was prevented performing my appointment.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Sir, I've no cauſe left to doubt i'th' leaſt your Honour, and do confeſs I was to blame in preſſing you too far; for which I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Could I but hope this Ladies, you have mine.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Ne're fear it, Brother, we are both come thus far to be Married, if we had your conſent, for I confeſs I am loath to go into the Countrey, and leave Mr. Merry unreclaim'd, for fear he ſhould be occaſion of ſome further Quarrel between you two.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: What ſay you, Madam, will you make good her word?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I to my Brother, Sir, refer the matter.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Then you are his; take, Sir, this Bond of Friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: A Chain ſo ſtrong, I hope can never break. Siſter, I wiſh you happy in your Choice.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Friends all, Friends all; why, this is fine i'faith: Now, Muchland, hang the Catch; come, paſs it by.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Not for the World: Come, the Wine there, and begin.

div.stage: A Catch Sung by Ruffle, Breef, and Fullam: They in their turns, Drinking, Kicking, and Cuffing one the other at the words to that purpoſe.

l.hi: WE are Gallants of the Town;
Men of ſprightly Breeding:
If Oaths will do't, we run e'm down,
But never come to Bleeding.
We meaſure Swords, appoint the place, and thither do repair too;
But Drink, Huff, Kick, Cuff; this is all we dare do.
At Play-Houſe we do count it brave
To have the Maſques Acquaintance;
'Gainſt Wit and Sence we alwayes rave,
And call't inſpid Non-ſence.
We meaſure Swords, appoint the place, and thither do repair too;
But Drink, Huff, Kick, Cuff; this is all we dare do.
In Coffee-Houſe we Battles fight,
And cenſure men of Honour;
We ſwear that ſuch a Ladies right,
And hath a Clap upon her.
We meaſure Swords, appoint the place, and thither do repair too;
But Drink, Huff, Kick, Cuff; this is all we dare do.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: That's done like Men of Valour.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Nay, Gad, I defie him that can ſay I fear.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Now you are all Friends, know, the Guard I made uſe of to ſecure you, are all Mr. Merry's Fiddles.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I'm glad I did not know ſo much before, I ſhould have broke their Priſon, or their pates.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: My Guard are ſomething a Kin to yours, Men very expert in handling their Feet, if a Man may ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: All this I ſee is a meer contrivance for a Dance; let's, without any more ado, have it then.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Come, Gallants, you think your buſineſs is done, but where's Roſe's thanks?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Roſe, I, Gad, I ne're dream't o'that; faith, Roſe, thou and I'le empty a Bottle ſometimes when thy Miſtreſs is in Bed, ſince thou'rt ſo good at Drinking.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: No, good Sir, Roſe is to ſet up in a better Imployment; for now Ruffle hath got my Old Miſtreſs, Roſe ſhall ſucceed in her place.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I got his Miſtreſs, don't believe him, Dear, I ne're kept Miſs in my Life.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis even ſo, but I give her to you freely; ſhe was true to me, and may prove ſo to you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: How, Marryed to a Wench.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Joy be with you, Valiant Sir; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Send you comfort of your Virtuous Lady; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Shall theſe Rogues laugh they cheated me of above threeſcore pounds to Night already? Make e'm repay me that ſum, I'le forgive all.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: We'l Dine together, and they ſhall pay the Reckoning.

sp.speaker: Breef.
sp.p: Good Sir, las, tis all we have to truſt to.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: No grumbling, Raſcals, if you do, I'le ſwinge you: But, Gentlemen, be tender of my Honour, and I'le take all; ſay nothing, I'le to my Eſtate in the Countrey, where I ſhall paſs for as Valiant a Squire, and my Wife for as Virtuous a Lady as the beſt there.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Well reſolv'd on, and I aſſure you I'le not Viſit your Lady when you are from Home, Roſe and I will keep cloſe together.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: But, Roſe, I hope you don't mean to take ſuch courſes.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: No, Madam, you may be ſure on't, Mr. Townlove's merry, and talks wildly, that's all; if he and I keep Company, it ſhall be meerly in Friendſhip; I would not for the World loſe my Reputation with him, I hope you have all better thoughts of me.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: No, Roſe, I'le warrant e'm thee and I will ſecure one anothers Reputations.
For want of Cuſtom wonder doth produce,
And ills do loſe that Name by frequent uſe.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: POets we juſtly may Wit's Babbles call;
For they to almoſt nothing venture all.
They with each Play their Reputations ſtake,
And ten to one, if good, it doth not take.
In thoſe that do, that part you onely praiſe,
Which Comedians mimickry doth raiſe;
So he, and not the Poet, gets the Bays.
But if by Chance ſome Writer does Extort
From the World's Vogue a pretty good Report,
'Tis ſo allay'd by but why that or this,
That he might juſtly wiſh 'twas none of his.
Hard Fate! Have they alone! All men beſide
Some Curtain ſtill, their faults to hide.
States-men their Errors on their Agents lay;
'Tis Chance of War makes Souldiers loſe a Day:
And your Phyſicians ſhame Death wipes away;
But every Fool finds faults in every Play.
Things being ſo, it cannot be deny'd,
But to be Poet is a man's blind ſide.
This is the cauſe why Active times produce
The feweſt Writers for the Stages Uſe.
The World is buſie now; and ſome dare ſay
We have not ſeen of late one good New Play.
And ſuch believe Shakeſpear, long ſince in's Grave,
In Choiceſt Lybraries a place will have.
When not a modern Play will ſcape the fire:
I beg their pardons who themſelves admire.
Not but this Age hath many men as Wiſe,
But wiſely they this begging Art deſpiſe.
And two to one, was he alive this Day,
He'd have more wit, then e're to write a Play.
His Fruitful Brain would find Employment now,
Which Times of drowſie Peace did not allow;
Then that you write not too, pray think your Eate,
Good lucky Poets, of your Sword and State:
And be not too ſevere on thoſe that do,
For all you Play hath it's Spectators too.
'Mongſt which there's ſome are Fools enough to blame
Our preſent War, the greateſt Scene of Fame.
The beſt contriv'd, beſt lead, and braveſt fought
Of all, in which England has Glory ſought.
Yet if Croſs Winds, or Storms do make you miſs
One Action, ſtrait Fanatick Criticks hiſs.
An Envious ſort of Sots, like ours i'th' Pit;
Who having none, ſtill rail at all have Wit.
Our Author, though, is ſafe, and fears e'm not,
His Play pretends neither to Wit nor Plot;
But ſhould you Damn it with your utmoſt ſpight,
When next he's idle, he again will Write.
